description:
I'm gonna be honest: this is one of those restaurants I'm tempted to lie about on Yelp. Because it's not overly crowded/busy. And I want it to stay that way. But they deserve the people's love :)

Flavors are close to 4 stars. 5 stars if you're evaluating it for what it is: a low key, casual dinner. Service is closer to 3 stars. Value (price : quantity *and* price : flavor) is a definite 5.

Zen Yai is my go-to place when I'm craving Thai but not trying to break the bank. It's an excellent value-play, each entree coming to about $9-11 bucks depending on your protein option.

Pescetarian / vegetarian options are plentiful. The standards (Pad see ew, pad kee mao) are great. I also love their spicy shrimp salad -- they use this amazing nice fish sauce vinaigrette that we sprinkle on other dishes ;)
author: Calvin C.

description:
My Thai friend said Zen Yai is the most authentic restaurant in SF, and I believe her!   I've been here multiple times but I'm only reviewing now.

The Thai boat noodle is a must-try and its only $8 for a large bowl! The soup is amazingly rich and deep in flavor and it comes with lots of meat, meatballs, fried pork skin, and spinach. 

Other dishes we loved:
Appetizers: Spicy shrimp salad, silver noodle salad, chicken satay
Entrees: Crab fried rice, Tom Yum boat noodle, duck noodle soup, pad see ew

They also have lots of Thai desserts at the counter like taro sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves and coconut milk custard jellies.

Zen Yai is probably one of the best bang for your buck places in the city :)
author: Katy Y.

description:
Had the papaya salad Lao style of course, Pad See Ew, and Combo #3. If you don't like the food here, sorry but... DO NOT have the audacity to say that you like Thai/Lao/Hmong/Miao food! 
This IS the place to be if you want legit good food for a GREAT price (especially in the city)!
The workers were polite and welcoming, and service was there when I needed it (refilling that water cup back to back cause of that spicy papaya salad)
I will DEFINITELY be back!!
author: Patrick X.

description: Love this spot! very authentic - reminded me of Thailand - the soup portions are perfect - they have small and large bowls.. the small bowls run about $5, literally a couple bites - we ordered the yen ta fo and the boat noodles and it was SOOOOOO good and flavorful - I wanted to order 2 more bowls - we also ordered the crispy pork crispy pork, which was cooked to perfection -- Wish we had more people with us so we could order everything on the menu -- we walked here from our hotel - i think parking can be a bit difficult and its in a sketchy area -- we saw some exchanges going on with people and syringes -- so be careful if you are walking in this area... I would definitely return to this spot - the food is on point!
author: Mimi P.

description:
This is a long overdue review for Zen Yai Thai.  This is my neighborhood Thai restaurant and I've been going here for over a decade.  It's one of the last restaurants that still serve good food at really affordable prices. The menu is vast and I really appreciate that they have several combos for those who want a little bit of a sampler. 

The chicken satay is my go-to appetizer and it really goes well with the pickled cucumbers and the peanut sauce.  Generally, I'd get one of the combo plates but I decided to get the seafood claypot at a recent trip. All of the dishes are solid. Thai iced tea is a must order.  

The restaurant is nice and big but the service can be a bit spotty.  I'd recommend this place to anyone in the area looking for some cheap Thai bites.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Arrived here around 7pm on a Monday night and there was no wait, but almost all the tables were taken. Parking was easy to find this time, but it's not always easy in the Tenderloin part of SF. 

We ended up ordering the silver noodle salad (medium spicy), tom yum boat noodles, and the all beef boat noodles both with silver noodles. All these dishes were super good and flavorful. The silver noodle salad was a bit too sour for my taste, but the spicy level was just perfect. The boat noodles were by far my favorite, and you cannot beat the price (less than $5 each! for the small size). Highly recommend the Tom yum boat noodles. 

Service was good as well. They took our orders right away and food came out super quick!

I will definitely come back to try their other dishes!
author: Stacey Y.

description:
Definitely a favorite in San Francisco. The flavors are solid! A little too solid - the papaya salad is a force to be reckoned with. Pungent! I personally haven't had it, but the table next to me definitely was chowing down. I'm told the papaya salad is a Northern version of Thailand, not what you would typically see in Bangkok. They incorporate raw crab to give that super pungent taste.

The food here is affordable! About $9.50 gives you an array of noodle soup options. I had the Tom Yum soup. Sour and spicy definitely warmed my soul, especially when San Francisco chilly winds don't give a @#&$ about your hair, nor your soul -- all while sunny!
author: Thomas K.

description:
Although this place is In the tenderloin, don't let that stop you. A good authentic hole in the wall home cooking place. Noodle dishes and papaya salad are excellent! Be careful when you choose spicy level though because Thai spice is spicy. Medium is already pretty spicy. The waiters and cooks all speak Thai so that's how you know it's good. 

The one thing i would not recommend here though is the green curry. Too sweet and watery. Otherwise other dishes are Delicious!! Will be back
author: Melissa L.

description:
My friends are always talking about this place so my fiance and I finally came with them to try it! Double date in the city on a Tuesday night. Might be hard to spot but Zen Yai Thai is across from the Civic Center Inn if that helps. Metered parking around the area but ya know, after 6pm it's free.  

Maximum capacity: 49

I ordered a large beef boat noodles (flat rice noodles); other options include vermicelli/egg/silver or thin rice noodles. The soup was flavorful, on the sweeter side, a tad bit spicy. The fiance got Crab Fried Rice and we shared the Zen Platter which came with fried calamari, shrimp cocoons & a sliced eggroll. My friends also got boat noodles. Was surprised that the bill was only $50! For 3 bowls of noodle soup, crab fried rice and an appetizer. You don't get a huge portion for the noodles but it was a good size for me lol. 

Service was so-so but good food. They also have snacks for sale in the cashier area. Don't like to eat in the city often due to the bad traffic, parking and high prices but this is a cool spot.
author: Karen L.

description: The food was delicious. The service was fast and ok. But a lilt too hard too find the parking spot near by the restaurant.
author: Chacha T.

description:
This is our favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. It's hard to believe how inexpensive it is. They have kids bowls of noodle soup for $2.50-$3.00. Their regular prices ranged six dollars tonight dollars. Where can you eat in the city for that price? If you have never been to Thailand, it is very similar to style than ordering. They basically how are you to order any of the foods that are not on the menu. It feels like being in Thailand for a couple of hours.

Our favorite is the crispy fried pork (moo kop) in the soups or with Thai broccoli (kana moo kop). We always order the fish cakes (tod mon pla) as well as fried noodles (pat siew) then experiment with other dishes. Never dissapoint

A bonus is at the counter when paying, they have packages of authentic Thai treats and spices.
author: Tommy J.

description:
This place came highly recommended by a friend living near SF. 

They have the usual variety of Thai dishes but the boat noodles were what the rage was all about. I like to sample a variety of dishes so the small boat noodles were perfect for tasting (you can order the large bowl as well which was probably 3 times as big). 

We ordered one of each: 
   - Beef boat noodle with thin rice noodles - dark and unctuous broth, a bit of a kick - definitely a must try. 
   - Pork boat noodle with thin rice noodles - same broth and flavor as the beef boat but with beef pieces instead. 
   - Seafood boat noodle with flat rice noodles - came out pink and tasted VERY vinegar-y. I wasn't a fan bc of the sour taste 
   - Tom Yum boat noodle with flat rice noodles - sweet and sour taste with garlic. this was average. Think tom yum soup with less spice and noodles added
   - Chinese Doughnuts - came with a side of condensed milk for dipping. Try dipping these babies into your noodle soup (without the milk). 
   - Papaya Salad - fresh, savory, kinda spicy and packed with garlic and flavor!

Place is great to try at least once but I left hella thirsty bc of all the sodium I consumed.
author: Allie D.

description:
This place is great! The boat noodles were unlike any other dish I've ordered at a Thai restaurant-- I honestly can't remember ever having something like this elsewhere.

The broth is this really rich and dark beef broth. It's balanced teetering on the edge of almost too salty, but the flavors are so good. I definitely *almost* felt bad about finishing nearly the entire bowl of soup. The large portion is plenty filling for a dinner meal.

You can customize what type of noodles and what types of meat you want in your bowl. I opted for the thin rice noodles, which are pretty similar in size to the noodles you would get in pho. Next time, I'd probably try the flat noodles instead so the broth clings a bit more to the noodles in every bite. The beef was just beef, not particularly memorable but it fit the dish well. 

The dish is garnished with what are basically chicharrones/fried pork rinds. It's odd, but I thought it worked well as a garnish on top of the dish. It's definitely a race against time to eat them before the soup makes them soggy!

The best part? This place is so darn cheap. Every entree we ordered, boat noodles and others, were all generous portions for less than $10. Incredible prices for a great and really authentic feeling Thai restaurant in San Francisco. The catch? It's in the tenderloin.. but this place is well worth the adventure getting here.
author: Tien L.

description:
Soooo good!! i odder Thai boat noodle, papaya salad, I love the test so perfect. I would like to recommend to try the food at this place. Yummy  
I will come back  for sure.
author: Bj P.

description:
Came here hoping to their their chicken rice since a friend of mine said it was pretty authentic, but unfortunately that was a weekend menu item only :( Boo!

Ended up trying their beef boat noodles which was super tasty and authentic. Their shrimp fried rice was pretty good too! We shared the fish cake appetizer, which went well with the hot sauce (beware, its super spicy!). 

Hope to be back some day to try that chicken rice!
author: Christina N.

description:
I heard about this restaurant from my friend who said he liked it, so I decided to try it out. Once I saw the menu, I knew exactly what I wanted 
- the FRIED CHICKEN OVER FRIED RICE! This is probably my favorite dish to order when I go to any Thai restaurant.

The fried flour part was very crispy and the chicken breast was tender. There was some flavor in the rice, but not as flavorful as other restaurants. Also, other places add a wedge of tomato in the rice, but this place didn't. However, with the price being only $8.95, I thought it was worth it! The food portion was perfect, not too much and not too little. I would come back here again and try the other dishes next time!
author: Wesley S.

description: The best Thai Boat noodle soup in United States. They definitely brought us back to the way we used to eat Thai Boat noodle in Thailand, the teeny weeny dish and the broth was way toooooo good. I wish from riverside to San Francisco is a little bit shorter so I will go to eat there every single day.
author: Ataya K.

description:
Talk about cheap delicious eats

8 main entrees + 1 Thai Iced Tea + tip and tax for 6 people was less than $85
Portions are generous and flavors are delicious
Seating can be good for larger parties
They take accept credit card

Overall Thoughts

Consider me sold on Zen Yai!
author: Eddie W.

description:
It's the most authentic Thai restaurant in San Francisco that I've been to and the prices are really affordable.

There's a secret menu in Thai for Thai Boat Noodles, Tom Yum Noodles, and Yen Ta Fo. They also serve Jok (Thai rice porridge) on the weekends!

I recommend:
PAD KA PRAO MUU KROB: Crispy Pork Belly with Holy Basil and chilies. This is a legit place because they use Holy Basil instead of Thai Basil. Holy basil is more lemony and peppery than Thai basil.

TOD MAN PLA: fried fish cakes with curry paste. These were handmade. Loved the bouncy texture of them.

These are also solid orders:

KUAYTIEW RUA: Thai Boat Noodles. These would be just okay if going by LA Thaitown standards, but we're in the Bay Area. I think the soup could be flavored more strongly with blood. I also didn't get any liver or blood cubes in mine!

KEE MAO EGG NOODLES: This is like pad Kee Mao but with chinese egg noodles instead. The shrimp were cooked well.

People here keep complaining about the TL. Honestly, it's not that bad. I walked to the place from Civic Center Bart on a Wednesday night and it was fine. If you don't bother them they won't bother you.
author: Gabriel H.

description: I ordered Thai ice tea and there is a cute lil fly in it. Service is terrible. Waitress has a weird attitude like I own her money. I understand this is a hard job and she must be tired, but at least squeeze a lil fake smile plz. Pad kee mao is the worst I've ever had so far. I thought the red pepper on the menu means spicy? How come I didn't taste anything???
author: Amy K.

description:
Yummy yummy place if you want authentic thai food this is a must. Homemade Thai food, you need to come and get the " boat noodles " popular here. 

Just hard to find parking and be careful what you have in your car not the  safest place but the food is delicious you gotta come and try it.
author: Hoa T.

description: I will gladly trek through the Tenderloin to eat here! I always order the beef boat noodles with thin rice noodle (the regular, not the combo, since I'm not a fan of tendon). Get these if you are looking for an intense flavor explosion! Every bite was steaming hot and delicious- the perfect comfort meal. I've ordered similar dishes at fancier Thai restaurants, but Zen Yai blows them out of the water.
author: Chloe Z.

description:
I've moved up to The Bay from LA recently. I was a frequent of Pa Ord, Hoy Ka, Ruen Pair, and Sanamluang back in LA Thai Town. I must say now that I've eaten at Zen Yai for 4-5 times, it's on par with LA Thai Town scene. If you are looking for authentic taste, inexpensive dishes, no fusion food or fancy food, straight from Bangkok scene, you come to the right place. Its located in Tenderlion for Bangkok street food authenticity.  

You won't be disappointed.
author: Ben S.

description: Went out of our way to find this place after a high recommendation from a friend and so glad I did! If you want authentic Thai food, this is the place - the music, the people, the spicy food (even when you ask for just a little spice) is legit. Had the phad grapow, the kana moo grob, and the green curry with chicken. All amazingly delicious. My only regret is that I don't live closer so I can come more often. I will be back!!!
author: Traci G.

description:
This place is consistent with other positive reviews on here. The restaurant is situated in Tenderloin so don't expect a fancy, traditional looking restaurant. However, it is a great place to go for an authentic, quick, good quality  Thai restaurant.

They have a a fairly extensive menu, nothing out of this world just good, honest, traditional food. I ordered a beef boat noodle soup and the portion was huge, real feel good food I thought and I was happy with my choice as I'm a big noodle soup fan.

The angel wings were super tasty with tangy, sweet, and spicy sauce. I also ordered Pad See Ew with crispy pork and I must admit, this place has the best crispy pork 2nd to the Thai places in Los Angeles. Another dish I got was the papaya salad with fermented fish and crab. It's very refreshing and has all the flavors of sweet, spicy, salty yet very balanced dish. 

The meal was really enjoyable. Good food for next to nothing? No wonder it was so busy!
author: Joe J.

description:
Zen Yai has a dirty hole in the wall establishment deep in the Tenderloin. It's definitely worth the trek to eat their "boat noodle" special.

There's plentiful seating, and service is nice. It's just inconvenient A F because it's in the shittiest (literally and figuratively) part of the city. 

I ordered the:
Boat noodle - fantastically rich broth, fishballs and an assortment of veges and meat. 10/10
author: Sean W.

description:
When dining out or snagging takeout in the city, you expect to pay a pretty penny, particularly with delicious food of any variety, but this place is super cheap for high quality and amazingly tasty stuff. 

My favorite is the Pumpkin Curry, which will only run you a mere $9.95 for an entire large tub of curry (takeout), which includes shrimp, chicken, huge chunks of kabocha, red peppers, and basil. You can opt out of the proteins if you want a vegetarian option, and add in tofu, just make cerain to specify it upon ordering. But jeez, $10 for a large portion that could easily last you 2-3 meals, feels like a bona fide steal. Do it, your stomach will be mad that you held out on it for so long. 

-Thai iced tea and thai coffees have such caffeine kicks that just a few sips will send you leaping across rooftops. 

-FREE DELIVERY on the Eat24 platform! Yes, this sounds like a billboard advertisement but hey, if you're partying in the city at someone's house situated upon a hill upon a hill and you just don't want to walk down to the Tenderloin or walk anywhere in general, free delivery is the bee's knees.
author: Alison A.

description:
My sweetie took me here for lunch this past Saturday, and it was pretty delish. :)

He's really into Thai food since he grew up there when he was younger so he's pretty picky with that cuisine. He said that this place was one of his faves in the city so he took me here. Lots of Thai people up in the place so that must mean they're pretty dang authentic. Haha

I got the Pad Thai while he got three different noodle soup dishes. I also got their Thai Iced Tea while he got the Thai Coffee which I forgot to try. Lol.. But I think everything tasted good. 

Of course, it's not really in a good area of SF. It's located in the Tenderloin area. It's like a diamond in the rough? Is that a correct term to put it? Haha..
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday at 7:45pm there was no line and a lot of seats.

We were promptly seated and given menus. 

I decided to go with the pork crisp over rice plate seeing that a lot of people were really happy with that dish but found it extremely underwhelming. There was a minuscule amount of meat and a heap of rice. 

My friend ordered the chicken fried rice and experienced the same thing in terms of the meat quantity, it was lacking.

The service was not the best too as I asked the sever for water and she ignored my first request serving others who came after us, without them even requesting water.

Overall this place was extremely underwhelming but I guess the plus is that the price for an SF restaurant was decent.
author: John A.

description: Cheapest non-fast food I've found in SF, and pretty good. Ran by Thais. Spacious space. Nothing fancy. They have crab fried rice. Not in the best neighborhood. I will eat here again.
author: Gloria T.

description:
The only authentic Thai Boat Noodle in SF!!! Feels like eating in Bangkok Soi 38. Feels like Im in Bangkok every time I eat here.
One of the best seller here is their Pad Kra Prow MooKrob 5 starts for that Crispy Pork Belly with Basil. Pad Thai is really great!!! I would definitely recommend this place fo Thai Food. 
Fried Chicken over rice is good and Som Tam Papaya Salad! All I can say is Aroi Mak Mak!!!
author: Mikoyan C.

description: The crab pad thai was great.  Actual crab. The fish dish was a bit spicy and fried, just too salty.  It needed rice to accompany the dish.  The seafood soup is still the best.  Had a big table next to us and i was salivating watching all the dishes they had.
author: Helen L.

description:
Came by for lunch the other day and it was a tasty experience at a fraction of the cost from Lers Ros around the corner. They do have secret menus here so be sure to read the chalkboards on the wall and ask if you need help reading Thai!

Started out with the Thai Tea and it was okay. Nothing too spectacular although it was half the price compared to Lers Ros!

The Seafood Boat Noodles were tasty. The broth had a slightly sweet flavor along with a nice kick to it. There was a decent portion of fresh wide rice noodles along with fish balls, pork blood, and some crispy wonton skins to top it all off. Definitely unique!

The chicken pad thai was decent and pretty standard. 

The crab rice was tasty, although Lers Ros has a much nicer rendition at 2x the price! :D They do give you a crab claw here too with the crab fried rice.

Their Thai sausage here is flavorful has a slight sour taste to it. It's the first item on the secret menu. It also comes with a side of ginger, cilantro, and peppers although I'm not too sure how to use it!

Their fish cakes here are okay with the ones from Lers Ros having a much fuller flavor.

Their mango with sticky rice reminds me of Thailand. Their sticky rice is served warm and their mango was very ripe and sweet!

The crispy pork belly with chinese broccoli was delicious as the flavor was on point with tons of garlic, although the crispy pork belly wasn't too fresh...

Their pandan dessert by the cashier was tasty too!

Staff is super friendly here too!
author: Derek S.

description:
I came here with a group of about 8 friends for dinner after the Chinese New Year parade. The service was fast and the food was sooooo cheap, around $7-$8 a plate. 

I ordered something recommended by a friend that wasn't on the menu called Bone Soup, which is like pho but has blood in the broth. It seemed like a daring dish, but oh my goodness did I love it! Rich, flavorful, and only $2.50 for a small bowl. I definitely recommend this place if you want some standard (and not so standard!) Thai food.
author: Chelsey B.

description:
I ordered chicken pad Thai, bbq chicken, and fried chicken over fried rice, and a Thai iced coffee through Door Dash and the food was delivered with the drink spilled in the bag all over everything because the server did not inform the deliverer that they had placed a drink inside the bag. 

I have never ordered from a place that put a drink in the bag with the food rather than handing it over. I was looking forward to eating the food at this spot since all the pictures looked so good, but looks like I'll be having coffee infused - chicken pad Thai, bbq chicken, and fried chicken fried rice instead...
author: Edward C.

description: I randomly found out about this place and went to yelp to read more about it before actually going so I knew what to expect and such. Like everyone said, the location of this place isn't the greatest. I actually missed it several times also. It's so small and easily missed. Inside the restaurant is nothing like the outside. The servers were really nice and friendly. Of course I came here to try the boat noodles. I tried all four kinds in small. I can't tell you now which one was which or the names but they were all tasty to me. I really liked it. It was all a little different. I think it was nice to try out all four different ones rather than getting one large bowl. Four small bowls and one order of sticky rice dessert was not even $20 yet! That's an unbeatable price! I will definitely add this place as a go to place when I'm in the area!
author: Trinh N.

description:
This is good, authentic, corner Thai food.   At lunch on a Monday most of the customers (6 tables worth) were Thai and the banter and chit chat in the space rang of Thai language. 


The food prices are very reasonable, and the food is on the oily side.   We had the Pad Kee Mao and the Seafood Hot Pot.    Both were good, perhaps not great, but fairly authentic. 

It did not disappoint, and in a city which is quickly becoming expensive, it is nice to have a reasonably priced corner joint.
author: Andrew D.

description:
If you ever been in Thailand, this is consider the most authentic thai food you can get. 
The boat noodles are MUST TRY both tom yum and beef. That is the solid  10/10
Papaya salad was good too 8/10
Everything else is ok.
author: Khang T.

description:
Very authentic Thai w/ reasonable price. I think there are the cheapest Thai resto in town i have seen. Although the menu are not many choice or fancy as others but you can taste the authentic one. It worths every penny for sure! 

Boat noodle is the must and also Yenta4. I quite not sure do they have in English or not but on the black board which hung on the wall, they wrote the menu in Thai lol . 

Dont miss this place! It's the place not only for who wanna experience Thai food but also for Thai people
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: Well, I gave 3 stars because I am not ok with stealing. I went there for lunch with my friends. Food was good. We used 2 cards to pay for total $62.76 which was $31.39 for each card. I tipped $6 for my card which is about 20%. 4 days later checked my online banking, it was charged for $41.39 which means they stole my money $4 dollars. They broke their trust. I am a broke full-time nursing student, that's why I watch every single penny I spend.
author: Sam T.

description:
Love the boat noodle broth here! It has got that amazing umami flavor that hints at secret and surprising ingredients. I like it with the silver noodles. The pork rinds, typical of boat noodles, add a nice texture and crunch.

This restaurant is located in the Tenderloin, so brace yourself as you are walking there, but it is worth it in my opinion.

Inside the restaurant is decently clean with Thai decor and a tempting display of desserts by the counter.

Definitely recommend as a hole-in-the-wall hidden gem in the city.
author: Sue V.

description:
I was walking around the Tenderloin, knowing I could definitely find a Thai spot around there. My boyfriend and I chose Zen Yai Thai for lunch and I'm so glad I did! 

I forgot to take pictures of our food because we were so hungry we started scarfing everything down! My boyfriend got the Combo #4 (BBQ Pork, Yellow Curry, fried wontons, rice and salad) and the Wings of Love. THE WINGS WERE SO GOOD! I got the Combo #2 (Shrimp Pad Thai, Yellow Curry, wontons, rice and salad) and the Fresh Spring Rolls. AND OF COURSE we got the Thai Iced Tea!
Everything was so amazing and our servers were great as well. My one complaint though is that it took a while for our water glasses to be refilled but that's okay - the rest of my experience here made up for it.
author: Gerone A.

description: Been coming back several times and its always been very good and cheap. The Thai boat noodle soup it's a must. I've tasted much of the menu and I'm yet to be disappointed. Will coming back for more
author: Bernardo S.

description: This Thai place is a gem.. cheap eats in Tenderloin for most of typical Thai dishes. Ask for Boat Noodles for what this place is known for among local Thais in the Bay Area.
author: Craig W.

description: I stopped by Zen Yai Thai Restaurant due to  closure (4-5pm) of other more popular Thai places in the area. Luckily for me Zen Yai was open so i could satisfy my noodle cravings.  The establishment has large and airy dining room, which was mostly empty at that weird hour.  I got a Zen Ta Fo noodle bowl. And Zen Yai Thai did justice to it. The broth had the distinctive red color and pungent but not overwhelming fermented tofu fragrance. It came with assorted fish balls, tofu, white mushrooms, tiny pieces with squid heads. I expected the traditional ong choy veggies, but instead got a few leaves of spinach on the bottom of the bowl. I wish it had real fresh shrimps and more squids. The bowl was barely spicy. I had to doctor it up with the dry crushed red pepper. I chose the flat rice noodles which I highly recommend. Overall, it was a satisfying bowl. Bonus was the staff was quick and courteous. I forgot my credit card and had no problem getting back. I definitely will return to try other dishes.
author: Thuy V.

description:
OMG the boat noodles here are must haves! I got the boat noodles with the thick rice noodles and it was out of this world, probably even better than the ones I had in Thai Town L.A. 

The grilled pork with sticky rice and it was pretty good too. The pork tasted sweet with some ginger/lemon grass flavor, similar to Vietnamese grilled pork/beef. Clay pot chicken rice was good, though it's a bit too saucy and not burned enough to bring out the rice flavor. This particular dish is somewhat similar to Malaysian/Singaporean style with lighter sauce. The fried chicken wing has the typical sweet chili sauce so it's less unique than other dishes. 

Living in South Bay I envy all the San Francisco folks who get to go to quite a few good Thai restaurants in Tenderloin!
author: Ken L.

description:
Been wanting to come for the Thai Boat noodles for the longest time (I don't really like going to the city, i can never find parking LOL), after many recommendations from friends and the disappointments of finding great Thai Boat Noodles in the East Bay, enough was a enough and I decided to venture out to the city and try this place out. I immediately found parking right across the street from the Restaurant and thought to myself, "this is it, this is the one that's going to be just like Pa Ord in LA. It's going to be a good day." We were greeted and seated immediately.

Food

My partner and I ordered the large Beef Thai Boat Noodle, the appetizer sampler, small bowl of Pork Thai Boat Noodle for myself, Thai Ice tea and Thai ice coffee. We received all our main courses before the appetizers. 

Large Beef Thai Boat Noodle: 

The flavor was on point. The broth was thickened with blood (how i like it and hard to find around the Bay). The broth was rich, spicy and with a light hint of sweetness. Getting Thai Boat in most Thai restaurants usually consists of typical beef broth and usually  hella sweet, not this place i can deem that Zen Yai Thai has the best boat noodle broth I've had in the Bay Area. 

With that being said, it wasn't the perfect Thai Boat noodle I was expecting. We had to wait a little for the broth to cook the Rice noodles a little more because it was still hard. the meatballs that was included with the noodle soup dish was expired. One bite into it it tasted sour with a funky after taste. We didn't want to be rude in front of all the people who were enjoying their meal so we just picked it out and enjoyed the rest of the ingredients in the dish. 

Small Pork Thai Boat Noodle:

This sizing is the typical size you'd get in Thailand and you can finish it off with one or two bites. it's exactly like the beef thai boat noodle but with pork balls and I can gladly say the pork balls were not expired and the noodles were cooked perfectly when it was served. The broth does get altered in taste slightly because of the pork, it was still really good but, i'd prefer the taste of the beef boat noodle.

Zen Yai platter:

We receive our appetizers last and at this point we were pretty full but, we still managed to finish most of it that rolled us into food coma zone. The dish consisted of deep fried calamari, shrimp egg rolls, and an egg roll with two sauces (sweet thai chili sauce and a regular sweet sauce). The calamari was cooked perfectly and tasted great. The Shrimp egg rolls tasted like what you get homemade but the shrimp was way larger. The regular egg roll tasted so fowl and in order not to spit it out in front of everyone I had to swallow it whole and wash it down with coffee immediately. 

End food review

The service was great in the beginning and like many Asian restaurants, once your food is out good luck trying to get some attention. Like another reviewer said many were in the back chatting it up and or eating. My partner had to wave to get some attention from the servers to get a glass of water and check. It's nothing out of the ordinary for what we're used to. 

The flavor of the thai boat noodle comes the closest to what i'm used to and i've been searching for the best one for about a year now and for now this is the best one i've had minus the expired meatballs (I've still have to to try the San Jose one, that's coming next). The food seems very authentic looking at other peoples dishes and the thai specials on the wall that's written in thai. The only thing i'd worry about coming here the the freshness of their ingredients so be careful other than that it's some good authentic thai restaurant that I'd come back to if i'm in the area but, not something i'd go out of my way for.
author: Alex T.

description: Great food, service, and atmosphere if you can make it threw the tenderloin crackheads and hookers on the walk here. I love thai food and it always scores points with my gf in bangkok. She translated the secret menus here for me and recomended some good stuff. I tried their trademark pork boat noodles and crab fried rice. The soup while full of good ingrediants and a great value at 2.50 was a little sour for me. The crab rice was hot and crisp right from the fryer and loaded with crab meat, scrambled eggs, onions, and tomatoes. For 10 bucks I had a delicious feast with friendly service.
author: Sean G.

description: This place is absolutely amazing!  Hands down authentic Thai with a very pleasant staff.
author: Rex C.

description: I was down in the Castro area and wanted to get dry pho in the TL but my friend suggested that we come here.. AND I'M GLAD THAT I GAVE IN!! My friend kept going on and on about how good the bone noodle soup was and TRUST ME it did not disappoint. I don't even know how to describe the soup except that it is super flavorful with just enough spice. You get to choose between beef or pork and the type of noodle you want. I decided to order the flat noodle with beef :) The portion sizes for the bone noodle soup are not like your normal restaurant.. so just fyi if you order a small it is the size of a rice bowl and if you want a normal sized bowl order the large!!
author: Mauricia L.

description: Favorite Thai place... in the United States! Big statement I know but the food is so authentic. Sometimes they're slammed and the service can come off as distracted but the food makes up for it.
author: Inar C.

description:
5 stars for the boat noodles. We especially liked the tom yam boat noodles. Our least favorite of the 4 was the seafood (but it still was pretty good). 

3 stars for the Duck Basil. Not bad, but not especially memorable either. We also ordered the fried squid, which was very average as well (but I kinda expected that honestly). 

Prices very reasonable, and portion size is good. I'll probably come back for the boat noodles...
author: Sean B.

description:
4.5

Good value here for SF and always friendly take out service!  Have tried the pad thai, basil chicken, fried wontons (best i've had) and crab noodles.  Everything has been great!  Good serving sizes as well.
author: Mike J.

description:
A little overdue here, but this place also has the best Pad Kaprow (Chicken & Holy basil stir fry + Fried Egg). This menu is written in Thai as the last item on the restaurant's blackboard, so it's probably a little hard to order. The dish is at its best when it's very spicy so if you love spicy food, this won't disappointed you.

Also Tom Yum is mighty delicious and authentic. Yum Woon Sen (silver noodles salad) is also pretty good. And of course the boat noodles are always the highlight. 

The only downside of this is the location of the restaurant. Also, the Thai menus aren't listed on the delivery website, so it's a little hard to order them for delivery.
author: Gott P.

description:
Waited 15 minutes and
1. Never got seated
2. Never got the menu
3. Never got water

The service here is atrocious, and although I understand that they are really busy here, there is no excuse to have people waiting to even be waited in the first place.

I was borderline about to leave, but since I was craving Thai, I decided to just get carry out instead. The Pad Thai I ordered wasn't really spicy even though I asked it to, and overall there just wasn't that Thai flavor you expect in Thai dishes. I didn't get enough of the classic Thai citrus flavor, and overall the Pad Thai was really bland. The biggest downside was probably that the noodles were stuck together and dry, which made for an even more unpleasant experience.

Prices are cheap, but there are lots of other great Thai options in the Tenderloin.
author: Michael Y.

description: Pretty good Thai food for really great prices and generous portions. I'm a fan!!!!!!!! I'LL BE BACK!!!!!!!!!!! I love the pumpkin curry!!!!!! Pad see ew was decent, but I love the portion, price, and taste of the pumpkin curry!!!!!!!
author: Annie S.

description: Yum!  Came here after a recommendation from a Lyft driver after he overheard me talking about how much I love Thai food.  We tried the boat noodle with beef, which was a new dish for me to try. And oh man was it good !  My favorite dish - so far. The pad khee mow  was also good along with the seafood dish. The papaya salad with crab and anchovies was a bit too strong for our tastes but I'm excited to try the regular papaya salad. Service was also great -friendly and fast. Will definitely come back again.
author: Fun L.

description:
A hidden gem in the tenderloin! Much, much better than the fancier Thai restaurants in the city.

Highly recommend the Tom Yum Kung, duck, fish cakes, calamari, and sticky rice. 

Keep in mind, there's no frills here. BYOB if you want something other than Thai iced tea or soda.

That said, it's DELICIOUS.
author: Courtney C.

description:
The beef boat noodle was really good, papaya salad tray $14.99 was also good. 
I would have to give 1 star for the location, it's really bad. Lots of homeless people, smells like urine on the street. Parking is bad.
author: Khiet E.

description:
I have had my share of Thai food in the city but upon walking into Zen Yai, you can tell this place is legit.  Everyone in here knows everyone and are speaking Thai and the specials on the walls are all written in Thai.  Husband's coworkers from Thailand recommended this place and told us this is where all the locals goes and they are right!  If you want authentic Thai food, this is the place to go.  

Zen Yai is known for their boat noodles and offers a variety of 4 different kinds starting at $2.50 each for a small bowl for either beef or pork.  The seafood + tom yum flavors are slightly more at $3.50 each or you can get their bigger size starting at $6.95.  Aside for their boat noodles, we also tried one of their combos and got a taste of the shrimp pad thai, yellow chicken curry, and fried wonton.  All were delicious, we cannot wait to come back and try more items.

Be sure to save room for their desserts as well.  Right by the cash register, they also offer a variety of Thai desserts from boba w/ coconut milk, sticky rice with taro, egg yolk pastries, coconut cake, and mung bean pastries.  

$10 credit card minimum and opens late for late night eats, don't overlook this gem if you are in the area!
author: Janetto L.

description:
I would recommend coming with someone who's familiar with the menu. They have specials written on the wall, and I believe you can order mini dishes like the pink noodle, drunken noodle, and the tom yum soup for pretty cheap. I'm not really a fan of sweet/sour dishes, so I ordered the drunken noodle with beef (large), and I enjoyed that. 

Their fried banana was also very good - very large and enough for four! They give you the option to add vanilla or coconut ice cream.
author: Jeanette S.

description: The boat noodles are what this is place is known for, however, I found the other things to be lack luster. For example I had the pumpkin curry which is also usually supposed to be good, however, the pumpking was WAY too hard which really ruined the dish for me. Moreover service here is meh, with my order of boat noodles getting messed up. Great thing is prices are pretty cheap for otherwise decent food. Also if you want to just give the boat noodles a try you can get a small bowl for $2.50 which is really a great deal. Very casual ambiance and they do free delivery with a minimum charge of $20. Will definitely give this place another try, and hopefully they get it right next time.
author: Michael C.

description:
Yummy and testy are closer Authentic Thai foods
And a good price for group party. 
Recommend menu 
1. Thai boat noodle , two choice pork or beef both good
2.bbq marinated pork /w sticky rice . Soooo gooood 
3.crispy pork belly/w basil or Chinese broccoli over rice + fried egg on top . Excellent !!!! 
Kind of secret menu only weekend
1. Rice Porridge 
2.Hai-nan chicken or Kao-Min-Kia is a garlic rice top with steam chicken and homemade sauce (very good) 
3.Papaya salad , 3 style.... 1.thai style 2.with crab 3.Lao style are all very good 

Who have any menu favorites plzzzzzz share ^^
author: Thitiphan P.

description:
I recently moved into the Lower Pac Heights/Tendernob area. As a busy, young professional, I depend on affordable and reliable take-out at least a few times a month. After trying out 2 other Thai restaurants only blocks apart, Zen Yai Thai has become my favorite so far! 

Zen Yai Thai offers delicious Thai food at a very affordable cost--most entrees are under $10, which is practically unheard of for a restaurant that serves food this good. While the area is expensive, albeit not as expensive as other parts of SF, I have found my spot! I highly recommend the BBQ half chicken, which is very juicy. I also enjoy the crab fried rice; it has real crab. Lastly, the combo meals are a great deal. I could easily make 2 meals out of it. I usually order combo 2: pad thai and chicken curry with rice and a side salad. 

I usually order delivery from the Yelp Eat24 app, but on occasion when I'm on my way home, I will order pickup. The restaurant, itself, isn't in a nice location. It is what you would expect the Tendernob to be--trash on the street and grimy. Inside the restaurant is more welcoming, but nothing fancy. Nothing like Osha Thai. No table clothes. No flowers. 

The more I go to the restaurant, the more I realize this place is a hidden gem. A few times, I've seen people bring friends or family from out of town. Even today, a family reserved a table. From the looks of the place from the outside, you would never guess how tasty the food. Part of me wishes, it will never be discovered, so it can stay a hidden gem.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Horrible to sum it up. 

Food is horrible. Tiny portion and bland.

Service is horrible. Chatty servers.

Rude server (old). I asked her about their combo because it was a little confusing for me. She gave me an attitude.

Uncomfortably cold. I guess the ventilation is poor that is why their windows are open. (Visit was during fall.)
author: Sarah L.

description:
Went for dinner. Very exceptional foods! But  "Bad" waitress!!!
She was so unpleasant and can't even say thank you at the end. The waiter was nice though
author: Amanda K.

description: Stopped in here on Pride weekend and it was really busy. With that being said the service and food was still great! One person in my group said his serving size was bigger then normal. The prices are really cheap also. 6 dishes and only paid $70! I'll definitely be going back.
author: Lawrence D.

description:
This is basically a Thai community center. If a Thai person comes in for lunch or dinner, he/she is very likely to run into a Thai friend. 

If you want to order Pad Thai, just stop it. Just don't. People don't come here for that. Zen Yai means wide noodle in Thai. Does Pad Thai use wide noodle? No. 

There are three types of noodle soups. 
- Boat noodle -- pork blood broth. Super savory.
- Yen Ta Fo noodle -- the broth is pink. The coloring comes from papayas and tomatoes or something like that. It comes with interesting things like white fungus, congealed pork blood, calamari, etc. 
- Tom Yum noodle -- don't confuse it with Tom Yum soup that you might know. They don't taste similar at all. The broth is clear and mostly on the sweeter side. 

These noodle soups come in two sizes. Go ahead and order all three in small. And you will be almost full. 

What comes next then? 
Papaya salad, Thai sausage, and Larb (minced pork salad with some refreshing herbs) are very good. Order those with an order of sticky rice.

What else?
They also have some Thai desserts. But I am not much a Thai dessert fan. So I will stop here.
author: Te R.

description:
Some of the best Thai food in San Francisco!
I loved all the dishes I ate here. I ordered the combination fried rice, the noodles with spicy sauce and basil, green curry with chicken and catfish in red/ chu chee curry. 
I tasted each dish separately at first to savor each one separately and just one forkful assured me that this was indeed the real thing. Some of the reviews did say that a lot of local Thai customers filled the place and that is always a good sign if you are looking for authentic cuisine. The prices are also among the lowest in the city.
I highly recommend this place. The location, while in the Tenderloin, is not that bad. I walked all the way on Geary and made a left on Hyde to avoid most of the dirty streets. Park a few blocks away if you are driving and you will be fine. I personally think that the Tenderloin on the whole is safe.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
TLDR - Cheap Thai food. Come here for the small bowls of noodles off the menu! They're the best in flavor and in value. Where else can you find $2.50 bowls of noodles?!

My friend recommended this spot for the cheap $2.50 boat noodles. It's not in the best of locations (hello Tenderloin!), but I imagine it's the shady surroundings that keep the menu prices down, so I'm not complaining. We stopped by shortly after 11AM on a Saturday. Relatively quiet and got a little busier around lunchtime but not crowded.

The menu they hand you has the typical things you'd find at Thai restaurants: noodles, rice plates, curries, stir fries, etc. Everything's pretty cheap around $7-8, $10 max. But what you really want is on the Thai menu on the wall; that's the real highlight here, the BOAT NOODLES. In Thailand, boat noodles are served in small bowls and people order many bowls, leaving tall stacks of empty bowls when they're done. Here, you can get a small size for $2.50, either with beef or pork, or you can get a large for $6.95. There's also small bowls of TOM YUM and YEN TA FO for $3.50, or $7.95 for large bowls.

My friends and I ordered 1 each of the small bowls - beef boat noodles, pork boat noodles, tom yum and yen ta fo. For small bowls, they were actually a pretty decent size. If you're like me and like trying several small dishes vs getting one large dish, these small bowls are perfect. 2 would probably be good if you have a smaller appetite; 3 if you have a larger appetite. Basically lunch for as little as $5! Not quite the prices you'd find in Thailand, but close enough.

We also got fish cakes as an appetizer and red duck curry to share, but personally, I would just stick with the small bowls of noodles. They were much more worth it from a cost, portion size and taste perspective.

* BOAT NOODLES ($2.50 small, $6.95 large) - 5/5
These were my favorite of the small noodle bowls. Dark, muddyish broth with thin noodles, beef or pork, meatballs, veggies and chicharrones. Both the beef and pork were tender, and the broth was deliciously bold and flavorful.

* YEN TA FO ($3.50 small, $7.95 large) - 4.5/5
Pink seafood noodle soup that included fish ball, squid, coagulated pork blood, veggies and fried wonton chips. Good flavor and a little spicier than the other noodles.

* TOM YUM ($3.50 small, $7.95 large) - 4/5
Slightly sweet, slightly sour broth with noodles, meat, veggies and fried wonton chips. I liked this as a lighter flavor profile in comparison to the other noodles, but it didn't impress me as much. I think there was pork liver in this one, so be careful of that if you don't like liver!

* TOD MUN / FISH CAKE ($6.95) - 5/5
Ever since I had fish cakes in Thailand, I've always wanted to get them at Thai restaurants back home but they've never been quite as good. The ones here were amazing! 

* RED DUCK CURRY ($8.75 rice plate) - 3.5/5
Not bad. Flavorful curry with duck, pineapple, bamboo shoots and bell pepper, but as far as curries go, it was pretty standard. The duck was more fat than meat, so I found this to be more just rice with red curry. I'd skip in favor for 2-3 small noodle bowls, which would be the equivalent portion size.
author: Jessie L.

description: This place was amazing! All the food was extremely tasty. Yellow curry, Pad See Ew & Pad Thai are a must!
author: Judy S.

description:
Great food for cheap. Boat noodles are absolutely delicious -- ~$7/bowl of really great spicy noodles. The size for a large is a standard bowl, so I wouldn't order a small size. I would absolutely come here again for the boat noodles, as that is what they're known for and I've never quite had spices like that! 

Their clay pot of rice was SO yummy. The meats and mushrooms were savory and very tender. Probably one of the best clay pots I've had for all under $10! 

Service was prompt. The location is a little sketch since it's close to the Tenderloin but what great food at such good value.
author: Cindy W.

description:
The over all food was great here, but there was lots of things unprofessional here, and Make me don't want to come back here again. Whenever I visit my family in SF we always come here for meetings and spend our family time. The food were didn't taste good as its always been but that's ok, since I'm not that picky on food. This time I'm by myself, I ordered 3 small bowls of noodle and couple of things Togo. I went to the counter to pay but they seem busy , to I left the card with the male server then I went to the restroom. I came out the restroom and found out that they lost my card. I mean like , how come you guy don't have responsibility taking care of customers card ? Or should I swipe my own card and make a payment for myself next time?? They ask me to wait until they find the card, but my parking are limited- I cannot wait that long and it's not on my responsibility. They did apologize , so what!? They didn't show any responsibility, I have to wait too long and be late for my work, I still have to pay my food in full price without 
discount... Well my sister told me I should have tell them that I only have one card and they lost it.... it's not my fault at all. I won't comeback again, since the food was that amazing anymore, plus there's still a bunch of restaurants that make delicious food. 

Sorry but things can't just be solved with just apology.
author: Phornphirun M.

description: Very delicious Thai food with very reasonable price. This is the 2nd time to come here. The photo is Combo 4.
author: M J.

description: There's a lot to like here... Lots of noodle choices, and they also serve chicken and rice (which we got to go).  The food is authentic and tasty, and the price is great for what you get.
author: Sun O.

description: Food was good but the service was slow for large group, especially one that had a reservation. There was a more than 30+ min delay from first meal delivered to the table and the last.
author: Wendy-Lynn M.

description: So delicious boat noodles with meatballs! We also ordered the spicy chicken wings and calamari as an appetizer. They were great. The prices were so reasonable as well. We'll go there again when we're in SF that's for sure. One thing tho that wasn't  impressive, it was the look of the restaurant itself and the cleanliness overall of the floor, tables, chairs, and cups. I think if they are willing to take my feedback, it'll be wonderful!
author: Rattikarn W.

description: Excellent food, service, and an unbeatable price. Definitely a gem among the many Thai options in the neighborhood.
author: Daniel F.

description:
This place is legit. Their boat noodle dish is one of the best noodle soups I've had. The broth is so flavorful. Pad Thai is perfect here. Everyone likes their pad Thai differently of course, but I like it just how it is here. It's not too tangy sour like some places, and it's not dry. BBQ pork... it's just damn good is what it is. Everything is just so tasty. 

This restaurant is a rare jewel to find in the city. Most Thai places are pretty expensive, but it's straight up affordable here, and I don't mean city "affordable". I mean plain affordable like lunch special affordable, and it's delicious. Cheap doesn't always equal shitty food, just like expensive doesn't always equal exceptional food. 

The only downside is it's in the TL and across the street from a seedy and sketchy motel. I literally saw a bum outside take out a syringe and shoot up right on the sidewalk, but... TL. 

One thing is for sure, if you go, order whatever your heart desires, but make sure to get the boat noodles. They have a small bowl which is just $2.50 if you just want to try it. Even for that price, you get a regular sized amount, not a rice bowl size. Try it!
author: Stacey L.

description:
* This is only for the delivery*

I met the driver at the door and asked him how much the total was to make sure i was giving him the right amount. Few minutes later, I got a call from him. He insisted that the amount I gave him was short when i actually gave him the exact amount + tip, he then hung up when I tried to tell him the arrangement of the money I gave him..  he knew I wasn't about to get swindled that night lol

great food though:)
author: Charly B.

description: It actually pains me to be giving Zen Yai two stars because the food is pretty delicious. My wife moved here from Thailand over a year ago and we've tried every Thai restaurant practically. Zen Yai is the only spot she will eat boat noodles. The flavors are very close to home she says: savory, rich, herbal, and delicious. I'm giving two stars because of service- in which I've seen a pattern with other reviewers who gave less than 4 stars. We dine here frequently and are familiar faces- dining at the restaurant maybe 3-4x a month. We will also make sure to grab a few of their snacks and desserts to go - adding onto our bill and tipping no less than 20% on the total each time. I would say, we are pretty loyal no fuss customers. Recently, we did nothing of the ordinary. After dining, my wife went up to grab some of her desserts to add on the total bill. A server (male, short, heavy build) screamed at her from across the room asking her if she was going to purchase it- berating her in front of customers and embarrassing her. 1) I understand he might have felt he was doing his job 2) his attitude isn't reflective of the Thai culture 3) we are repeat customers. I know restaurants can become arrogant and lazy when people return for their food and they become a popular destination, but this isn't any way to treat any customer. San Francisco is becoming a revolving door for small businesses, I would think the owners would want everyone to feel welcome and retain their loyal following. On that note, his treatment of my wife was bad enough for us to make a decision to cut down our trips to Zen Yai. There are several other competing Thai restaurants, especially talented chefs who are offering more authentic esan flavors. This is a true and genuine yelp review: not trying to bash the place. I think customers should also be treated with respect as much as restaurants and chefs demand it for themselves because it is true hard work to keep a business going.
author: Michelle M.

description: The crab fried rice is awesome!!!All of the dish is beyond average and price is reasonable!I really recommend people to try their Thai boat noodle soup on the wall,but hope them have the English version!My Thai friend took me here first time and I really addicted to this restaurant!They don't have obvious sign outside, just find the red building on the corner!
author: Ting-Shan Y.

description:
Some of the best restaurants are always in the most unassuming areas. Unfortunately, Zen Yai resides in one of the more challenging neighborhoods in the city - the Tenderloin. But do not fear children! Lock your cars, hope for the best, and head on over to Zen Yai for one of the best bowls of boat noodles you'll ever have! 

Thai beef boat noodles come with a savory reddish black broth that is packed with delicious full-bodied flavor, your choice of chewy thin or wide rice noodles, a beef ball, spinach, and crispy chicharrones (fried pork rind). $2.50/small bowl or $7.00/large. They also come tom yum style with a sweet and sour soup broth. You'll see many patrons with multiple small bowls of noodles at their table, so order up! Oddly enough, the boat noodles are NOT found on the menu. You'll find a discrete white piece of paper pasted on the back wall with the off-menu special. Boat noodles are not commonly found in Thai restaurants, so definitely take advantage of the opportunity to try them here! 

Thai iced teas and coffees are a must at $2 and the pad thai, pad kee mao, and papaya salad are dishes I've tried and enjoyed here. Open until 1am on Friday's and Saturday's, Zen Yai is one of my favorite places to go after an evening out with friends. Especially, if you only want a small, but satisfying bowl of noodles to warm you up and end the evening on a high note. Good service, inexpensive prices, and the best place in town for Thai boat noodles!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Was extremely fortunate to come check this place out with my Thai friend, who tells me this is a pretty authentic place to get Thai boat noodles, and really satisfies the craving. It was really cheap, too! I definitely could have eaten more than 1 large bowl of it. I had the dish with beef and flat noodles. The broth was really flavorful, and quite spicy. There was a hint of sweetness, but overall very fragrant. I thought the beef was bland and pretty overcooked. We also got a shrimp salad to share. It was a collection of chopped tomatoes, cucumbers, cilantro, and a few shrimp. Not super impressive, and the sauce all collected at the bottom. Overall, a tasty, authentic place to eat, but not really my favorite Thai place in the city.
author: Ke C.

description:
The best boat noodles outside of Thailand (confirmed by Thai friends), and they are only $7 for a large bowl. This tastes like nothing you've had. Extremely flavorful and complex. Seriously, you won't know what hit you. If you're not full from one bowl, get two. Again, it's $7 a bowl!!!

Two best dishes! Order like this: 
- Boat noodle: Nam Tok (means noodle soup darkened with blood - for first timers, this sounds weird but trust, it's very tasty. Say "Nam Tok" or you'll get normal beef broth), wide noodles, large size. It comes with meatballs and chicharrones on top. Ask for extra chicharrones if you're into them!
- Kana Moo Krob (crispy pork belly) - get it with rice and egg on top

For the love of food, do not get your typical pad Thai, pad Kee mow, curry, etc here that you're used to getting at Thai places. It's a waste when there's heavenly boat noodles waiting for you.

Tom yum noodle soup is also good!
author: Inga C.

description: Very authentic Thai food. We came here as Thai students in Boston to travel and we ordered 7 different dishes. They were all crazy crazy good. One of the best Thai restaurants in the States I must say!
author: Bookkiez S. P.

description:
My coworker brought me and another coworker here for lunch one time because it's a short walk from our office building in Civic Center. The exterior doesn't look like much, but it's very misleading because the food here is delicious and so affordable!!

I ordered a small order of the boat noodles which was $2.50. YES, ONLY 2 DOLLARS AND 50 CENTS!!! And yes, they were as amazing as the other reviews say. Don't question it, just get it. I've never had boat noodles before, but now I want to get them at every Thai restaurant I go to! Get the small as an appetizer, or get the medium size for an entree. It's totally worth it.

My coworkers both got the combo #2 which comes with pad thai, yellow curry with chicken, rice, salad, and wontons. This is ONLY $8!! Probably one of the best deals in the TL because it is so much food. I ended up eating some of their huge portions because I didn't know the small boat noodle was so tiny haha.

I would probably visit Zen Yai again just for the boat noodles alone... They were that good!!
author: Tara A.

description:
When in doubt, order every ffffin item from the BBQ list. S'how I roll, bizznasties. #doyouevenorderallthefoodsbro

Delivered in an hour. Considering I solo ordered enough food for 3 people, the wait time and $33ish price (after tip) were deece. Good portions on $8.95 entrees, especially in SF. #firstfoodproblems

(^_^) BBQ Pork Spare Ribs
Moist, springy, sweetish.

(^_^) BBQ Kalbi (Marinated Pork)
Sweet w subtle garlic. Perfect w bagoong.

(-_^) BBQ Chicken
Ok. Less flavor blast than the others.

Not foodsnob or #ohyoufancynowhuh dishes, but I'd ring 'em up again to quell a Dr. Jekyll x Mr. Hangryde episode.
author: Dan B.

description:
I really think this place is a hidden gem that is slightly misunderstood. I suspect this place is fairly authentic based on the patrons and Thai written menus on the wall. I really enjoyed their papaya salad and the minced spicy chicken dish (can't quite remember the name). The boat noodles were ok, but I think I need to order a few different kinds and try a bunch rather than just one. If you ask the server what the menus on the wall are, they will gladly explain it to you. Servers were always nice to me!

Definitely give this place a try and see for yourself!
author: Devashis R.

description:
Still my fav!

Love the wontons, boat noods, and now I order the off menu prad ka prow moo krob (crispy pork belly with chilli and basil and rice)
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
I had pretty high expectations of Zen Yai since I had been told the food is the most authentic experience you can find outside of Thailand. 

I split the pad kee mao with tofu, and vegetarian yellow curry with my friend. Both were great! I appreciated that the noodles were flavorful but not soaked with oil. 

Portions are generous, and prices are low! However, it's not located in the best part of SF, I would come back again if I were taking a Lyft directly to and from the restaurant; but strolling through the neighborhood, even in broad daylight, made me feel a bit uneasy. Just something to be aware of :)

I already have plans to order delivery from here. Yelp Eat24 offers free delivery with a minimum purchase of $20. Just a good excuse to add the papaya salad (minus the fish sauce) to my order this time!
author: Sarah N.

description: The food is good, price is super reasonable, I don't taste msg, been coming back there a couple of times in the past two weeks. Can be a regular soon
author: Kevin L.

description:
The food is amazing, but the service isn't.
We were waiting for awhile with a lot of empty tables, and no one came out to even say, I'll be right with you or we are waiting for an empty table. Just standing there. I think they just need more employees.
author: Dat N.

description: One of the best and authentic Thai restaurants in this neighborhood. We ordered larb, catfish and their amazing boat noodle (p.s. they don't have it on their menu but just ask for it). This is definitely one of the cheapest places to eat too, probably due to the rustic neighborhood. Highly recommend.
author: Alexandra T.

description:
We tried going to Lers ros thai, but it closed for a break from 4pm to 5pm grrrrr.  So we ended up going around the corner to Zen Yai and I'm glad that I did.  This place is legit, too bad we couldn't read the specials on the wall because they were written in Thai.

Service is definitely slow here, however, they make great Thai food.  We ordered the boat of noodle, wings of love, green curry and fried rice.  The boat of noodle was awesome and it was only $2.50.  The wings were good but not sang tung good, the green curry was delicious.  

This place is great, I just wish the waiters would've told me what the specials were since I don't speak Thai (siamese).  Next time I can probably do without the wings and try their Pad Thai.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: The food is always on point and consistent. We would come here everytime we're in SF for authentic Thai food. Their price and portion are reasonable considered they are located in San Francisco. If you want to switch up your papaya salad game, try Loas Style. Overall experience always good.
author: Kimheak L.

description: I waited food for 50 mins. It's not even rush time. And it usually and normally happens!
author: J K.

description: It's one of the best places you can eat tai food.  I ate combination fried rice with pork spare ribs and they are delicious!!! The prices are great and the staff is friendly too. Recommend this place without any hesitation.
author: Fedor S.

description: They used to be my favorite- order accuracy and best pumpkin curry were highlights. Consistent and fast delivery. Things have changed, and they don't deliver anymore. I'll find a new place
author: Piper W.

description: Food is five stars, but the service just made me feel uncomfortable. Me and my bf seen a flyer come out from the meat as we are eating. We asked the waiter, and first thing she said to us was:"if the flyer was in the dish, it was supposed to be dead". She didn't even say sorry. she  gave us a new plate, but the way she explained just let us feel disrespected.
author: Liang J.

description: Food did not show up.  Eat24 was unhelpful and cancelled our order without an immediate refund. Attempted to call the restaurant directly but there was no answer. Maybe it's good, but don't bother to order through the yelp app on a Friday night.
author: Mark W.

description: Delicious food and cozy environment! Love this place! We ordered the small size noodles, turn out to be good noodles sampler!
author: Panda B.

description:
Authentic Thai ?? This is the place .. My Thai Roommate who's always get his home cook Thai Food here... One roommate loved the Fried Chicken.. Other one the Pad Thai .. I get the BBQ pork was just amazing ...get the Crispy Pork Basil .. Too .. For a person who does not eat rice .. I'll eat it with all the food my Thai roommate brings home ..

Location is not really the best place .. But then I'm looking for the quality of food .. I'll definitely come here ...
author: Donovan L.

description:
I love Thai food, so decided to give this place a try after looking at all the Yelp reviews. I got takeout and I have to say that I am pretty impressed. I wish I tried a more "adventurous" dish, but that's for next time.

Like a very basic person I got their Pad Thai ($7.50). Only 7.50 for that giant serving? Wow! One of the better Pad Thai I have eaten. I love how they give you raw bean sprouts, because it adds a different texture to the dish. Also, I love how it's "deconstructued" with the toppings on the sides. I just wish there was more sauce.

Overall, pretty good Thai place, but then again I only ate Pad Thai haha. Will come back next time to eat more adventurously for sure.
author: Vivienne C.

description:
Their noodles are the best. Boat noodles, Tom-Yum noodes, Yen-Ta-Fo are all great. Boat noodles if you like thick herby beef broth, Tom-Yum noodles if you like hot and sour (thai chili and lime), and Yen-Ta-Fo if you like sweeter taste. I always go for Sen-Lek (medium-sized thin rice noodles).

They also have porridge (Jok) if you go Friday night or on weekends. The toppings are great and exotic: century egg, liver, and other pork organs.

They no longer have homemade desserts made by the Thai auntie in the area :(. I tried their fried banana for the first time and it was good, it comes with coconut ice cream by Mitchell's. They go very well together!
author: Norases V.

description:
Listen to everyone else and get the boat noodle dish. Large is only $7 or something like that. It's not on the menu so make sure to ask for it; one of the best meals I've ever had sub $10

Not a great area, though - recommend going there with a friend if you're walking
author: Matthew R.

description: This is my second visiting this place. The price went up a little. The taste is very good . I would happy to come back again.
author: Amenda S.

description:
TL local here. I love Zen Yai! Don't come in expecting out of this world customer service...especially during rush hour. Some waiters are better than others but at the end of the day they get the job done. 

Bomb food. Great prices. Filled with locals. 

I've eaten at their location and have gotten delivery. Both are good and quality is always consistent. This is my go to spot for thai food in SF! This is the first place I went to after coming back from college! I usually get large boat noodles with beef. It's really rich, really flavorful, and really spicy! If you ask for spicy, you gonna get spicy. They don't skimp.

Psssttt...up where the register is, they sell thai sweets/desserts that are not on the menu and can not order.
author: Anna H.

description: Friend of mine introduced me to this place, and I'm glad she did. We all tried their famous boat noodle soup and they were amazing. They got different flavored broth, I tried the pork flavor and I just want more.
author: Tan D.

description:
Service is beyond horrible and rude - the guy with the glasses was rude. I asked the other waitress lady for a box and a check, didn't get that til 6 mins later, after my husband had alrdy finished the food. I was only able to get the check because I went up to the counter to ask for the check AGAIN. I was here from 12:00 for lunch and my husband didn't get his fried rice until 12:40. The table that came after us got both their entrees. 

Boat noodle (beef) was good but way too spicy. They piled at least 2 spoons of pepper on top. 

Come here if u would like mediocre food, bad service and have at least 1.5 hours for lunch. Or else there are plenty of good restaurants around.
author: Tammy F.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 3.0/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 2.5/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

Very good authentic thai food at a reasonable price.  Boat noodles were great and worth trying, and rice dishes were good all around.  I'd say about half the diners there were Thai.
author: Damian W.

description:
Ever since I heard that this place had boat noodles for $2.50, I knew I had to check this place out! I finally came here the other day with 2 other friends. One of my friends and I each ordered a small boat noodle and shared a combo with yellow curry and pad Thai. 
The small boat noodles were really good! They included fried pork skin which added a good crunch. I try to limit the amount of salt in my food, so for me, the broth was a bit too salty but my friend thought it was fine. I also expected it to be bigger but it's only $2.50 so I can't complain! 
The yellow curry and pad Thai was a good dish to share with someone after eating the boat noodles. Didn't stuff us till we couldn't move but didn't leave us hungry for more. The flavors were on point and it was a great pick for Thai food!
Overall, the price(~22) was good for 3 people! It's hard to find a good deal like that, especially in SF!
author: Betty L.

description:
This is my new favorite spot for Thai food in the Tenderloin. The boat noodles are sooo delicious! It's not on their main menu but is listed on the wall, only in Thai, so unless you can speak or read Thai ask the waitress and she can guide you in the right direction. 

I've probably tried 8 different dishes here at this point and neither one disappointed. Price is also very reasonable.
author: Cyndi G.

description:
Oh yes. Go early while they still have the Thai desserts on the counter. You have to pay separately so don't be embarrassed to go score some before they sell out. The kanom tuay are out of this world. Have only had stuff this good in Thailand. 

The restaurant was packed with Thai people. How often does that happen. I had red curry vegetables with brown rice. Solid and delicious. My wife had padsee-ew. She loved it. She was taken here for lunch by a Thai fellow she works with. I don't remember what they had but I'm looking forward to returning.
author: Marco M.

description: My party and I ordered a dessert. Both waitresses saw us waiting for it and after 25 minutes of waiting, we decide to tell one of them to cancel our order. She then comes back and tells us the kitchen forgot our order. Unacceptable and irresponsible. Why else are be sitting there with no food, not asking for the check? Follow up with your guests. 2 star food at the best: fried platter lacks flavor, chicken curry not memorable. Expected better based on prior reviews.
author: Victor H.

description:
An authentic Thai eatery on the outskirts of the tenderloin, where local Thai people go to enjoy Home style cooking. Down to earth staff and great service too at a reasonable price.

Highly recommend their papaya salad and garlic pork rice plate. Wash down the spice with a cool palm juice. We will be back again.
author: Rosie R.

description: Fast delivery, delicious delicious food and cheap! Definitely our new go-to place for delivery. Yum!!
author: Katie S.

description:
3 and a half stars. I round up because of the free and fast delivery (was quoted a little hour an hour but it arrived in about 45 minutes) and pretty good prices. The delivery items were also packed in nice containers that showed thoughtfulness (for example, the thai iced tee was not only in a plastic bag but also had tape on the lid so it wouldn't spill).

Pad Kee Mao with Shrimp: Excellent price ($7.50 I think + $1 for shrimp) and while the portion was not the biggest, it was definitely fair. I requested this to not be too spicy and upon opening it, I was a little scared by the number of jalapenos on top. They were basically just there for show though, I removed them and this was actually pretty mild, especially for Pad Kee Mao. Adding some of the jalapenos back was the perfect amount of heat for me. I enjoyed this and liked that it had a good amount of veggies as well. I would order this again. 

Pumpkin curry: Tried just a little bit.Not the best pumpkin curry I've had in San Francisco, but it was alright. The chicken in it was far better than I expected it to be (I really liked it actually) and it also had a little bit of shrimp. Lots of pumpkin as well which I liked. I found it to be a little bit too heavy on lemon grass and spicier than I like my pumpkin curry.Requested that if they provided rice, it would be brown rice, but the order still had white rice. I think I would skip this next time (because there are a lot of other items on the menu that look promising) but it wasn't bad by any means. The portion of curry was also super generous, and a good deal at about $10. Again, the price was definitely a good deal. 

Thai coffe: Really good, and again, cheaper than most Thai restaurants ($2). It was pretty strong and not sickeningly sweet. I enjoyed this and would get this again as well.

Overall, definitely a solid spot to deliver from and I would definitely choose this place again.
author: Seema U.

description:
I've been coming here for several years now. Still a big fan, but I found myself coming here less regularly. I recommend the duck noodle soup, the pad see ew noodles (stir fry noodles with soy sauce), and congee.. among other things, like the bbq pork, curries, etc. This flavors here are pretty authentic. Service is reasonably quick, and I've always been able to get a table..

I just got delivery today and it was pretty solid. Pretty reasonably priced. Took about an hour. The duck noodle soup and stir fry noodle with soy sauce were just what I was looking for!
author: James S.

description: Got a medium spicy veggie pad see-ew. Average. Didn't blow me away
author: Sonya J.

description:
Really good Thai noodle bowls that you can't find at run-of-the-mill Thai restauratns.   Ask for the dishes that are off the menu: 1) Tom yum noodles, 2) Boat noodles.   You have a choice of chicken, pork, wide noodles, thin noodles.  Approx $3.50 for a small bowl, $6.50 for a large. 
 Location is not stunning, and the atmosphere isn't the most romantic (but still better than most utilitarian SE Asian restaurants), but food is really good.
author: eric s.

description: Great food... great price. Definitely recommend it if you are looking for some Thai food in the city.
author: David M.

description:
This place is EVERYTHING. Come here. 

Whas this I hear about boat noodles?!? Here's a breakdown: 
- They're not listed on the English menu. They're listed on the wall in Thai writing. 
- You can get smaller samples for $2.50- $3.50 a bowl. 
- Choose your own creation with these options- 3 broths (pork blood, sweet/ sour, plain), 3 noodle (wide rice noodle, thin egg noodle, vermicelli), and 2 meats (pork and beef)
- Boat noodles come with good variety of toppings, which vary depending on which one you get- beef balls, green onion, chicharrones, fried won ton, etc. 

We sampled 4 boat noodle bowls, and THEY WERE SO GOOD. I will come back for these, especially now that I know which flavors I like the most. 

We also ordered the pumpkin curry (a customer favorite) and the spicy chicken salad (chicken larb). Loved both of them. Curry comes with rice (we got brown rice), and the chicken larb has a spicy kick. 

Prices are extremely affordable here. Pumpkin curry was $9.95; Chicken larb was $6.95. Yes, this is in a rough neighborhood, but it's obviously a popular place. It was busy for a weekday lunch.
author: Joanna L.

description: Super authentic thai food -- all the writing on the walls were in thai.  Also, our family that came in from Thailand requested to eat here because they had been there before and it was legit--they also spoke to all the wait staff in thai when we ordered.  $2.50 for the thai boat noodle dish--can't beat that price!  You can choose from thick noodle or thin noodles--my group got thin noodles.  The soup is a little spicy.  It has meatballs in slices of meat in it as well.  It was a pretty good size for $2.50!  I got the tom kha which is enough soup to feed a small family, and the chicken satay, which came with yummy peanut sauce.  They also have some thai desserts that you can get to go (but we didn't get any).
author: Miss Maggie C.

description: Even I have my favorite boat noodle in Los Angles but this place is my go to place for Thai boat noodle in San Francisco.
author: San J.

description:
