Best boat noodle soup in San Francisco. The pork or beef broth are both excellent in flavors. They come with your choice of the fat rice noodles or egg noodles. Their papaya (Lao style) with a side of sticky rice are a must. Their basil pork belly is out of this world. My family and I drive 40 minutes to dine here and we come very often. It's worth the hassle!

One less star because they make everything super super spicy even when you tell them repeatedly to make it mild.
author: J.J. P.

description:
Giving a 4 stars because of the location and things and people around it!
Portions are a little smaller than usual but taste really yummy. 
Ordered a pad-see-ew veggie and tofu and the noodles were cooked very well!
Ordered a pineapple fried rice and it was a little wet but still tasted good. 
Also ordered a duck basil rice plate and the duck was pretty decent! 
When the bill came, it was a little surprising but hence the one dollar sign for this restaurant. Would recommend if you're looking for a smaller portion and something cheaper than the places in SF to eat!
author: Kristie L.

description:
1. Our friend got a glass of water with a dead fly in it (not moving, so it's been there for a while).
2. They messed out he order
3. The food wasn't good. My Pad Kee Mao was half bean sprouts, quarter onion and barely any noodles. All the dishes lacked in taste. 
4. The portions were so small that we actually had to go next door to get full. Our bill for 4 people was 60$ and it totally wasn't worth it.
author: Justyna M.

description:
Placed an Eat24 order. Ordered some reliable Thai food here. Can't say it beats Lers Ros, but I wanted to try a new Thai place near me. 

Pad Se-Ew Noodle with chicken- chewy, tasty noodles, light amount of gravy, good amount of carrots and onions ($7.50)

Tom Yum Soup- generous amount of vegetables, but not as tangy in flavor as I'd like ($7.50)

Thai iced coffee- cheap at $2, but not as good strong or sweet as Lers Ros or Thai House Express Castro
author: Thomas L.

description:
FOOD: 
Get the boat noodles here!! It's only 2.50 for the small bowl! That's my favorite thing here and I love it since the soup has plenty of flavor. The meat is thin slices meat and you can choose to get the noodles thick or thin. That's the main thing worth mentioning here. 

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Yes.
author: Kelley Y.

description: I love their Tom Kua (sea food), Thai BBQ chicken, Pumpkin Curry and Original Thai bowl noodles soo much....friendly , sweet waiters and delicious food. AND.... AND AGAIN ! The prices are really rational！
author: Allen O.

description:
I came here on a Tuesday with my wife. We looked at photos and read reviews on Yelp before coming here. Also, my sister loves this place and rates it high which added to the hype. The boat noodles looked so delicious which is what mainly lured us to come give it a try. 
I ordered a beef and tom yum boat noodles. I thought the flavors were OKAY.  will give them credit for their noodles. I got the regular rice noodles and loved the texture. However the flavor was more on the bland side. I am going to compare this to SAPP and Pa Ord Thai restaurants in LA. The taste does not come nearly as close as these two restaurants. So 3 stars for their effort.
I would come back when I am craving boat noodles but will continue to explore other restaurants until I find the one with the "right" flavor in the bay area.
author: Janet S.

description: Ate lunch here. This is next door to Project Open Hand. I ate here long ago when restaurant was under another name. Street meter parking. Thai food was excellent for what we ate. Tasted authentic. Tables and chairs relatively clean. Service was fairly fast. Good value for tasty food, most entrees were inexpensive.
author: Clifford W.

description:
I'm surprised I've never tried Zen Yai, even on the Eat24 app, before last month since I tend to show up at most of the popular spots in the Tenderloin at one time or another. What finally drew me in was all this talk about their Boat Noodles. I didn't know what they were, but I figured I like noodles and I've been on a boat, so what the hey. It's on that stretch of Ellis that veers between sketch and scary, sometimes at a moment's notice, but now that Rusty's Southern has moved in across the street, maybe this can turn into a gourmet ghetto. Anyhow, I came in and found there was just a handful of customers in what appeared to me as a fairly spacious place.

There's quite a bit offered on the menu as you can see (photo: http://bit.ly/1Gp3WSk). However, I came for these Boat Noodles which were most definitely off the menu. That gives them the cachet among Yelpsters especially. I found out there were two sizes - $8.95 for a large bowl and $2.50 for a sampler size. Perfect, sampler size please. It was definitely a sliver of a portion, but they managed to get a lot in the baby bowl like a muddy-looking broth with rice noodles, spiced pork strips, a strange white meatball that I pray was safe to eat, and all these pork rinds on top (photo: http://bit.ly/1DGbARl).

I just found it odd, somewhat tasty but basically a miss compared to a good bowl of pho. I'm not sure where the boat part comes in, but I felt like I was in steerage. The rest of the meal, however, was quite good. First off were those $7.95 Zen Yai Spring Rolls. They were filled with shrimp, tofu and vermicelli as you would expect but wrapped with an extra-thick rice wrapper that lent a nice chew (photo: http://bit.ly/1QqzJ84). It was particularly sturdy when dipped in the peanut sauce. For my main dish, I went for the $8.95 Seafood Eggplant which I requested have just calamari. Not sure why, diva moment I guess. It was tasty marinated in a basil and chili sauce and accompanied by rice (photo: http://bit.ly/1Gp3CD9).

I've come back with Jamie W. on a couple of occasions now, and other dishes stood out such as the $7.50 Pad Se-Ew (Drunken Noodles) with Chicken, Broccoli and Carrots (photo: http://bit.ly/1bzJOjw) and the $7.95 Duck Noodle Soup which was full of the quack (photo: http://bit.ly/1ExEIRg). I was less in love with the $6.95 Wings of Love, chicken wings which were deep-fried and coated in a heavy spicy-sweet sauce that made a trip to the cleaners inevitable (photo: http://bit.ly/1aX79dE). Nonetheless, It's starting to feel like our go-to cheap Thai spot for now.

FOOD - 4 stars...sure wish I missed the boat on those noodles but the rest is very good, especially those spring rolls
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...relatively spacious though it gets crowded fast
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...first visit it was great, subsequent visits were spottier
TOTAL - 4 stars....good Thai is always worth keeping in your mental rolodex
author: Ed U.

description:
Always get the red duck curry. Excellent food. Best thai in the bay. BBQ Pork is fantastic. Quality food every time.

Their pad thai sucks though.
author: Tera D.

description: My favorite Thai food place in the Bay Area. Price-friendly. Great food. I would order green papaya salad, Spicy Basil and green curry every time.
author: Ying Y.

description: My family and I came here for lunch and was so excited to eat good Thai food. We ordered so much and when the Tom yum came, we noticed a little critter floating on top. It was a cockroach! We immediately told the waiters and they took the soup back. My husband is extremely allergic to roaches and we left right away. Went to the pork exchange and it was awesome. Come here if you like extra protein in your food.
author: Bnb L.

description:
Came here on late Sunday night, by recommendation of a Thai friend. I had called beforehand to make reservations but when I arrived, it was completely empty .. imagine my shock and worry.. 

Not to panic though, the food was amazing. I ordered my usual pad kee mao with chicken, and the rest of my table ordered garlic pork w/ rice, pineapple fried rice, and coconut curry soup. Everything was delicious !!! And I felt like I was back in Thailand. Gathering from the other yelp reviews, they are most famous for their boat noodles so we also got an order of that right before the kitchen closed. It's only $2.50!!!! A steal compared to other SF prices. Not to mention, our total bill was only $45 split amongst 4 people ... your wallet won't cry after visiting Zen Yai Thai. 

I also have to give plus points on its location - it's right next to the northern end of Polk St aka close to all the bars and perfect for some late night drunchies. Parking is also ridiculously easy. AND if you read my previous review, no cockroaches :)
author: Annie L.

description:
Very bland for a Thai restaurant, and small portions (hence the slightly lower prices)--PASS on pad Thai, pad kee Mao, Tom kha soup, etc....

I've frequented this place solely for theIr crab fried rice (spicy is spicy, decent amount of crab).  That being said, the only good things about this place are the crab fried rice and that they're open late.

Severely lacking customer service and horrible delivery.  Staff is confused, and Manager is both confused and defensive.  4 hours and several personal and Eat24 phone calls later (90 min in, 2 hours in, etc.), still no food.  Order delivery at your own risk.  

After the last disappointing display, they've lost me as a customer for good.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
First, to be fair, the food here is good for the price.  I've been going here for a while now, but unfortunately I won't be coming again anytime soon as the service is absolutely atrocious.  

Being a big fan of the floating market noodle soup after visits to Thailand, I had asked a simple question about possibly substituting noodles for rice, a very common request.  At the time, I received a pleasant "no" from my waitress and with no matter in mind I placed a regular order.  I didn't think much of the situation but soon after she went back to the counter and criticized me in front of her coworkers about my question.  What made it even worse was that she knew I heard her and still continued to do so.

Wow - Just a simple question and I get treated like this.  I didn't realize I was dealing with the Soup Nazi of Thai Food.  You may want to be cautious of asking any questions when you come in.

I look forward to patronizing Sai Jai which is right around the corner.  Although Zen Yai has some dishes they don't, overall they offer a larger menu with the same price.
author: Mike M.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE ZEN YAI. I used to come here as a child all the freaking time when it was Racha Cafe, so when it became Zen Yai, I was kind of skeptical, but I am glad that Racha's Signature dishes -- Tod Mun aka Fish cake, Spicy Squid (can ask for less bamboo shoots upon request), and Minced Beef with mint are still done Racha Style! If you are going to try something, order these, and a pad thai or pad see ew. Order these.. And you are set for the night for a reasonable price!  You can also ask how hot you would like added in your dishes. ASK AND YOU WILL RECEIVE. 

In terms of service, I always see new young servers and they always seem to be training. Don't get me wrong, they are super pro active, but sometimes are going too fast and check up on the customer more than necessary. Other than this, the food comes really fast and they are on point with re pouring the tea -- one of the best teas at a Thai restaurant in SF I might say. Again, I am still sad that this is no longer Racha, but I am happy that it has the same spirit and great Thai flavors with it!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: Uh bomb, homestyle Thai food. Some of those dishes are mind blowing especially this one with fried noodles in broth. You can get a ton for super cheap. Also a great hack is you can BYOB. I did that with a bunch of co-workers and it was the best time. Love this place. If I had to say one thing they could improve on it's just the environment. It's not really an impressive place to talk people on that level, but once they try the food it doesn't matter. Try all the foods here!
author: Dexter H.

description: Decided to try this place out for the first time last night! I decide to try it because delivery was free and the food was cheap so of course I didn't expect much. Boy was I wrong! The delivery was super fast it got to my house about 45 minutes before expected which was great! As for the food I was pleasantly surprised! I didn't really expect that the portion sizes would be as filling as they were since the prices are about half that of competitors. It was also super flavorful and fresh. I will definitely eat here again!
author: Catalina P.

description:
Here again! Got 2 small bowls of namtok and tomyum noodles

They were indeed very small but it was bery yummy and authentic


Service was great
author: Sarah T.

description: Zen Yai has shot back up on my list. The place seems a lot cleaner as well. The boat noodle is still hands down the best. Rad Na is also done very well. Welcome back to koalies list.
author: Koalie W.

description:
This place is definitely a good local Thai restaurant.
The prices for the food are very reasonable and the food are really good.

I usually order the beef boat noodles with rice noodles as it's probably the best boat noodle in town.

It's a must try and it's open till late! The location might be alittle scary as there are a few homeless people strolling around outside but it's not as bad as it looks.
author: Alui L.

description: This place is simply a must stop by Thai restaurant. The food is delicious and the service is great. Everything on the menu is truly done well. So if you're looking for some good Thai stop by.
author: Joe G.

description:
BOAT NOODLES $2.50 / $8.95 - (4 STARS):
$2.50 for a small bowl, I'm in! The boat noodles were the most flavorful thai noodles I've had in the city. $8.95 for a large. Unlike most places, they don't skimp on the veggies and the chicharon on top is. I wish it was a little less salty, the broth can sometimes taste way too concentrated. Note: this is not listed on the menu.

EGGPLANT CALAMRI (2.5 STARS):
I liked the flavor because it reminds me of Amphawa's yolk seafood stir fry, but the squid was very chewy and there wasn't much of it. There also was just a little eggplant which tasted too much of oil, and the dish was composed primarily of sliced, raw onions. 

SPICY CALAMARI ($) 4 STARS: 
This is definitely a very fishy smelling/tasting dish, but I enjoyed this combination! It was a fairly generous portion of squid compared to the eggplant calamari. For a Thai restaurant, I was impressed by the quantity and I liked that it didn't taste overwhelmingly like frozen seafood..

Pro-Tip: Visa/Mastercard (no AMEX).
author: Jess C.

description: Boat noodles are excellent. Most dishes seem authentic and validated as such by my Thai gf
author: Mark K.

description: The organization I work with brings large groups to this restaurant and they are always super accommodating. They have incredible Pad Thai and it is my favorite place to eat in the TL.
author: Lyndsie F.

description:
I came here for a late date night.  We ordered garlic pepper pork, two orders of the boat noodles, and spicy green papaya salad (Laos style).  The place is located in the Tenderloin so with few parking so we started the night with a Lyft ride there.  

The garlic pepper pork was delicious.  The green papaya salad could have been a bit sweeter.  I wasn't too impressed.  I think Champa Garden on ocean Ave is consistently better. We finally tried boat noodles for the first time.  We anticipated that the amount of noodles would be small but it came out way smaller that I expected.  It was probably enough for two-three bites.  I would recommend ordering one at a time and deciding if you want more after that.

I would probably come back another time (earlier in the day).  I'm giving a three star because I wasn't too impressed.  Nevertheless, you can tell that the workers work hard and I appreciate that!
author: T K.

description:
This is the Thai restaurant of my childhood so I have a bit of a sentimental bias when I say this is my favorite Thai restaurant. My dad used to work at City Hall and would take me here when it used to be called Racha Cafe-- long before the Yelp era so that's how you know it's real lol. We even ate here on Racha's last day but thankfully they kept the same menu items that I love. Three signature Racha items that keep me coming back-- Spicy Calamari, Spicy Chicken, and Tod Mun (Thai fish cake). I can't seem to find equivalent dishes at other Thai restaurants! It's pretty cool because my dad would always order these three, and ever since the restaurant became Zen Yai, these are the only menu items that say "Racha Cafe's style" in the description. The flavor is the PERFECT combination of basil, jalapenos, and chili pepper. When ordering the spicy calamari, I do suggest asking for less bamboo so you don't get skimped of actual calamari. Other than that, these are must orders.

Moving on, I also love the tom yum soup here because they're very generous with whatever meat or seafood you decide as well as the mushrooms. SO MUCH MUSHROOMS, I love it. The pad thai and pad se ew are also really good. Curry wise, my cousin went to Thailand and got me hooked on curries with a fruit component. Now I always get the red duck curry because the pineapples are such a delightful contrast to the richness of the curry. My mom doesn't like duck so yellow curry with potatoes is also a solid choice. Pair all these with some thai iced tea or even just their hot tea with pandan and you're in a great place.

More recently, my bf started ordering the Zen Yai Fresh rolls, papaya salad, and crab meat noodles. You just can't go wrong with this place! The fresh rolls are different because the wrapper they use is more like a large rice noodle than the usual spring roll wrappers. Papaya salad is a little on the spicy side, but it's a great healthy addition to a protein and carb heavy meal. I was also pleasantly surprised by the amount of crab in the crab meat noodles.

My favorite part about this place now that I'm older and frequently eat late-- They close at 1AM on Fridays and Saturdays and 9:30pm the rest of the days of the week. You can also order pickup or delivery through EAT24
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: Love going to this place every time I visit SF. The Variety of Noodles that they offer made me feel like I'm eating right from The street in Bangkok. Never get enough from Zen Yai. Som Tum Pla Rar is another thing I have to make sure that will be on the table. Lil sketchie area but worth to go.
author: Guntvaryn T.

description: Flavors are ok, and inexpensive. However, the place looks dirty (just look at the nasty menus) and you have to dodge sketchy looking people outside and that makes me want to never return.
author: Apple M.

description: Fast, simple, delicious Thai food experience in the Tenderloin district of SF. I love how late they open!
author: Esperonsa M.

description: One of all time favorite and go-to thai restaurant. I have been going here for years and it's definitely a well-hidden gem in the TL. Their food, flavors, price are amazing!! I would definitely recommend their papaya salad, fresh rolls, pad kee mao, boat noodle and fried rice. The only downside is their hours since they close pretty early, otherwise it's definitely worth a try.
author: Linda L.

description: Interesting spin on a lot of their dishes. Some taste amazing and have a great combination of flavors. Others are a little strange. Try many things when you go.
author: John L.

description:
I love Zen Yai restaurant. In my view, this place has the best Laotian styled papaya salad and boat noodles. The food reminds me of Thai street food I ate growing up.

 Highly recommended.
author: Salisa K.

description:
We ordered delivery through EAT24 from this restaurant. We found metal pieces in our pad see ew. My child's mouth was cut and he almost swallowed the pieces. When we contacted the restaurant,  they didn't care. The woman who speaks english, just repeated "well" several times, as if we should expect metal in our food.  I will not order food from this business again. 
UPDATE: After posting this review, The restaurant contacted me and issued a full refund and an apology, in addition to agreeing to pay the medical bills incurred as a result of this unfortunate incident. (+2stars)

The Tom Yum soup was mostly lemon grass and mushrooms, two pieces of tomatoes and   4 shrimp. The flavor was very bland. I asked for non spicy, received no flavor. 

Besides having metal in it, the Pad See ew was so oily. 

Yellow curry had only chicken and potaoes was bland, when removing the spicy.  Good portion, though. 

Cashew Chicken, was half a container of liquid with three tiny pieces of bell pepper and 2 cashews , and a hand full of onion and stringy 2 oz of chicken.
author: J. G.

description: I was recommended to try this place by many Thai people. Zen Yai definitely has legit boat noodles and yen ta fo. Tom yum noodles are alright but not as authentic as the first two. You can either get a small bowl for $2.5 or a large bowl for $6.95-$7.5 with a choice between pork and beef. Their late night menu is also pretty good - they serve porridge and you can pick different toppings for each bowl, such as salted eggs or boiled eggs. I also got a local Thai dessert 'kanom-pia' from the counter which was really good. However, don't expect good customer service from here. The servers are usually in a rush and give an attitude when we request for something.
author: Pitch M.

description:
2nd time to Zen Yai Thai Restaurant so hubby could try it.  It's easy to get here from Civic Center Bart, short walk.

It wasn't busy when we went, but filled up more while we were eating.

I like 3 small bowls of the Thai menu on the wall:

Guay Tiew Yum $2.5 x 2 - so yummy.  Get it.  I gotta remember to ask for No bean sprouts & no liver with Fat Noodles, I need 3 bowls next time!

Boat Noodle $3.50 - Blood soup w/ pork.  Still not my favorite.  B. liked it.

B. got Fried calamari and said it was really good.

Can't wait to go back.  Charge it.

Separate bathrooms in the back.
author: Ann L.

description:
Very surprised I've never been here before since I frequent the TL often for the bomb ass authentic Vietnamese foods. Anyway, Zen Yai got bumped into one of my all time favorite places.

First time coming: got 4 of the sampler noodle soup bowls to share between the bf and I. I don't remember what they are specifically (one was a beef, and my favorite was the Tom Yum), but they all tasted so heavenly. Each bowl was absolutely rich in flavor and I would definitely grab a full size in one of each. 

2nd visit: Open on Christmas Day! And this time, I got the full size of my favorite of the sampler bowls! The Tom Yum noodle soup with clear glass noodle. The full size this time, however was a little too spicy for me. Next time, I'll make a note of getting it non-spicy. Again, the soup base was absolutely flavorful, and I love the peanuts in it. The chips thingy (I don't know what it's called) thats on top was my favorite part of the noodle soup as well. 

Clearly, I'd definitely come back.
author: Harriet W.

description: I ordered spycy basil prok rice. It was so yummy that I ate all. I love this restaurant and will come as possible as I can.
author: Jiaqi L.

description:
THIS PLACE IS RIDICULOUS. 1) Dirt cheap (delivery was pricey, but that's on OrderAhead--not Zen Yai), 2) really tasty food, and 3) enormous portions. My two friends and I each ordered our own dishes, but in reality, one curry and a salad would've been more than enough for all three of us.

We ordered the pumpkin curry (comes with rice--delicious without being too sweet and full of delicious chunks of pumpkin and chicken), green curry chicken (doesn't come with rice), a side of rice, and a papaya salad (+ shrimp). I stuck to my own curry, so I can't comment on the other dishes, but everyone loved their food, and delivery was quick in spite of the rain.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I love coming here. The food is good. I don't live in San Francisco but I come here every week.

Tonight I checked that the restaurant closes at 9.30 pm so I called ahead and asked if I could order ahead. The server said I can come in and they still serve. I got there at 8.30 pm I thought I would have enough time to dine in. The lady server sat us down the the corner table then the guy asked us if we can get it to-go. Wow! I drove 2 hours to get a take out order? Disappointed!!!!!

The other servers are nice by the way.
author: Tida T.

description: Amazing! If you've been to Thailand and miss the authentic cuisine, here's the perfect spot!
author: Denise T.

description: Delicious and love that they have free delivery!! We got the pumpkin curry, the combo plate (pad Thai), and the pad see ew. All phenomenal. They also got the spice levels right!
author: Hannah S.

description: The lunch combo plate was great!  Had the one with the Pad Thai and Chicken Yellow Curry. It came with Salad and Fried Won Ton. Great deal!
author: Elaine T.

description: Service was horrible! It wasn't even packed when I went and I had to get up to get my own menu because they forgot our table. She was so fast to take our order right away when I just grabbed the menu and didn't even take a look at it yet. On top of that I had to ask her to get us water because she forgot. Food took so long to arrive that by the time we got our appetizer the spoons she given us were dirty and not clean at all! There were left over food stuck onto it from the last customers. Ordered the famous Thai boat noodle that everyone loves in a size small and come to find out it's only one piece of noodle and all greens only. Wasn't satisfied with my food at all and their pad Thai tasted bland. Never coming back here again!
author: Lina T.

description:
I ate here Saturday evening 2/25/17 with a group of friends. I ordered the pad see ew with chicken. I finished the plate and on the way back to my car my stomach began to turn. I immediately knew I ate something wrong. 

I threw up twice, heavily, within 1HR of ingesting the food  and vomited 6/7 more times till 3AM the next morning. 

Sunday(2/26/17)- I was bed ridden the whole day with a fever, chills,a severe body ache, loss of appetite, and very low energy levels... Classic case of food poisoning

Things to note - I was with a party of 7 and no one else got sick from their food but, no one ate from my plate. (Plates were being passed around to share) 

I am certain there was something up with the chicken, wether it was not prepared properly or not stored correctly, which lead to me getting sick...

There are too many good Thai restaurants in the city to have to go through what I went through...it felt like the devil was coming out of me after that meal...

So if i were you, id pass...
author: Jordan L.

description: Ordered through Eat24 and I accidentally placed a future order. The restaurant called me to confirm if I wanted my order immediately or the next day (as originally ordered). I was so shocked that they called to confirm! The rep said that if I wanted it immediately, the wait would be around 90 minutes, which I okayed. They ended up delivering within 45 minutes!! Amazing service, delicious food, great value!!
author: Raeann L.

description:
Really authentic Thai noodles! 

We tried boat noodle, tom yum noodle and Yentafo. All of them were very authentic and delicious. I like that you can get them in the smaller size so you can try them all! They were as good as you can get in Thailand!

We also tried the green curry fried rice which is really good but it might be a bit too spicy for some. Lastly we tried their "joke" which they only serve on Friday night and weekend, they are good but not amazing.

The service can be quite slow but still very friendly.
author: Tiratat P.

description: Very nice people despite my Gluten Free challenge. I didn't really expect them to make any adjustments for me, but they were willing and ever so careful. We had a huge group for lunch too! I was the only one with gluten allergy, so I only order pad Thai without soy sauce and they prepared everything separately. The curries all had marinated meat, so I  couldn't order those.Surprisingly, the pad Thai wad absolutely delicious and I didn't get sick. My family enjoyed the whole BBQ chicken,sticky rice, regular pad Thai, veggies...everyone was very happy. Thank you!
author: Janine M.

description: Generous portions and affordable! I would never have stumbled upon this spot except for friends that live in the neighborhood and are regulars (literally, one friend I dined here with was eating his third straight Zen Yai meal). I got pineapple fried rice and my friends ordered pumpkin curry and green beans/beef - everything tasted/looked excellent. An unassuming place, but I definitely appreciate that in the masses of delicious but overpriced alternatives in SF.
author: Connie Q.

description: I always order the Boat Noodle with wide noodle at Zen Yai Thai - which is not on the menu. This "secret menu" is no longer a secret - seems like everyone knows about it by now coz it's delicious! I love the pork rinds they put as a topping - I always take them out of the bowl to prevent them from being soggy. It never disappoints and I come back time and time again just for the Boat Noodle. I sometimes get their boxed snacks - sold at the register. I get the rice balls with peanuts and sugar filling. Try them and you won't regret it! :)
author: Priscillia I.

description:
Updating my original review to let you know to NEVER come here on a Saturday evening or perhaps, not for dinner at all. We experienced such terrible service as they were completely understaffed. After about 10 minutes of being seated, I had to ask for the menu. Additionally, not one server asked us what we wanted to drink. Finally after about 15 minutes of sitting there twirling our fingers, we were served water. Not only did our orders take forever to come out, but the servers forgot what we had even ordered. Seriously? Get it together, please. 

Their authentic Thai dishes and food from the secret menu is delicious (and cheap). Certain dishes catered to the general American population actually kind of suck. Also, I'd suggest more meat and less lettuce in the fresh summer rolls. There are always a ton of local Thai people dining here so that definitely suggests their authentic Thai menu is on point! 

I couldn't decide what I wanted so I ordered both the Tom Yum noodles and Boat noodles: $3.50 each! Best part about the entire meal!
author: Thao T.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE. After returning from my trip to Thailand since December, I have yet to find a place that has boat noodles. What are boat noodles? Amazing broth made of pork blood for the most part.. The flavors sit extremely well in the noodles itself. It is served with a bit of morning glory veggie, fried pork skins, and some pork meat balls. As you can tell, I ordered the pork rendition of this dish. You can also ask for it in beef. The traditional way is pork; i like tradition. ***It also comes with dried chili so make sure you ask for it without if you can't handle the heat. 

The tod mun aka fish cakes are amazing here. I love that they have just the right amount of spice to it. The best part of this restaurant is really that they serve miangkham. Let me just say, get it. They only sell this to you in cash. It's in a container on top of the counter. Take all the ingredients provided and wrap them in that leaf - also provided. Eat the whole wrap with one bite and taste all the flavors that burst like a rainbow of texture, savory, salty, sweet, sour, crunchy, chewy delectables. 

I love this place. So much I'm going back tonight.
author: Marlene T.

description:
One of the best restaurants in SF hands down! Value for money: ~$22 for 3 people (inclusive of tax) was great!

We tried 2 yellow curries and the boat noodles special ($2.50 for a very small bowl). Everything tasted wonderful and service was pretty quick! 

I'd recommend this spot as a go-to lunch place during the week, although it can get busy during lunch hour if you go on the early side of things.
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is vetted. Better Thai food in San Francisco is something that doesn't seem to exist. Bring the whole family (bring your own booze), eat like royalty, and then marvel about the negligible amount of weight your wallet has lost. Everything here is good. I don't like pineapple, but their pineapple fried rice is off the chain!
author: Abe A.

description:
This is as authentic as it gets. It is very, very difficult to find 1) an authentic Thai place that 2) makes great boat noodles. This place ticks both boxes. Plus, it's served in a way that is similar to how it is back in Thailand: in small portions.

The broth of the three bowls of noodles I got (yes, three) was savory and delicious. The rice noodles were just right. They even had crispy pork skin, which is just like back home.

I think that the waiter service leaves a bit to be desired, as do the condiments provided (no chili vinegar? Saaad). Nonetheless, that doesn't detract too much from the excellent food in a casual setting that truly does harken back to places back in Thailand.

I've been back to this place twice in two weeks, and hope to make many pilgrimages there before I am forced back Midwest!
author: Pat O.

description: This unassuming Thai restaurant has some great authentic dishes. A few of my favorites include the Hainan chicken and the Tom yum noodle soup (all of their boat noodles taste different). A lot of their best options are off menu and written in Thai on the chalkboard. Highly recommend this place for a quick, casual meal -- small or large party.
author: Shirley L.

description: I fell in love with this place. Excellent food, great service and family ambience! For sure will come back for more red curry duck!!
author: Juan H.

description: Delicious Thai food with a one-star penalty for not delivering to the apartment door (unlike every other place in SF I've ordered from). It might sound petty, but the reason I order delivery is because I don't want to leave my apartment. If I'm already going downstairs, I might as well just order pickup from around the corner and then not have to deal with a delivery minimum, delivery tip, or being available at the exact time when the guy arrives. But the food is really good.
author: Jon C.

description:
There is definitely better Thai food in San Francisco than Zen Yai Thai. I decided to give this place a try after hearing a lot of good things, but unfortunately, I was not impressed. You can tell this is true, authentic Thai food because when you go here, most of the customers are all Thai.

I tried the veggie red curry and the veggie pad see ew. The red curry had the weirdest curry taste I have ever tasted in a thai curry. It had almost no flavor, but the little flavor it had was not good at all. I definitely don't recommend this. The pad see ew was better. I liked that it came with a lot of different veggies, but I honestly couldn't taste much besides just soy sauce in the seasoning. 

Overall, I was not impressed and will probably not be back! If you're looking for good thai food, try Thai Idea just down the street, it's all vegetarian (but it's still amazing!).
author: Malika R.

description: Boat Noodle is addicting, love how they have good small portion sizes for a good price!
author: Lena N.

description:
I love Zen Yai! WARNING: It is NOT your typical Americanized Thai restaurant. Come here if you want authentic food. 

I come here to eat Thai Boat Noodles and Hainan Chicken Rice. They have the best of both here. Thai Boat Noodles are these brown broth colored noodles with meatballs (YAAASSS).

Hainan chicken rice IS SO GOOD HERE. I always get it here and they always have the SAME CONSISTENCY. ERHMARGErd!!! And the sauce that they provide will make you feel like you're back in Southeast Asia. 

Thai Ice Tea is pretty delicious and they also have various Thai snacks by the counter if you want to try their delicacy.
author: Cindy M.

description:
We came here for the boat noodles and were not disappointed! We ordered it with beef and wide noodles. I asked to have it made WITHOUT blood. Important to call this out so that there are no surprises when you get your order. It was so delicious!!! $2.50 for the small bowl was perfect to get a taste of the boat noodles. It was 5 bites. I wish I had ordered a large bowl as a meal though. There were different chilis and the broth was tasty - spicy and flavorful. Felt like comfort food! 

We also ordered the pineapple fried rice which my hubby enjoyed. 

Papaya salad was a little overdressed to my liking. I was hoping there was a little more fuego/spicy kick to it. 

The Sa-Koo Sai Moo was so good! It has ground pork, ground roasted garlic, peanuts, tapioca pearls, preserved radishes, and palm sugar. The server said it was considered a dessert but it can be enjoyed as an appetizer. It's savory, salty, and sweet. Make sure to take a bite of cilantro with each bite of the Sa-Koo Sai Moo balls! Such a great complement.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Their standard Thai fare is below average (See my previous reviews).
The only reason why I am bumping this ish up is because of the BOAT NOODLES.

Damn Zen Yai, why you gotta be so shady and have it posted in THAI ONLY!? Non Thai folks love boat noodles too, don't deprive me!

While Zen Yai's boat noodles are nothing compared to the ones I'm used to (Pa Ord, SoCali love! Props to my boy Smitcha on that tip!) it is decent. Needs a tad bit more flavor so I found myself adding fish sauce and peppers. You can do a small bowl which  only costs you $2.50 while a large is $7.95 (a bit pricey IMO). You have a choice of thick rice noodles or the regular thin ones. 

I'm staying away from their lunch specials but only returning for boat noodles. If you don't know what boat noodles, then well.. Shit. You're missing out. It's a Thai beef noodle soup but made with blood in the broth. For those faint of heart you can be a pu$sy and order it without blood.
author: Susy C.

description:
LOVE Zen Yai.  I order it in (free delivery) too often.

The whole roasted chicken is the best and fairly affordable.
author: Ryan H.

description: Anytime I'm near City Hall or the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC), I walk a few blocks and order one of my favorite dishes, Pad Yang Plate, boneless roast duck with rice.  They have a pretty extensive menu, but the roast duck is my favorite.  I would rate it higher, but the service is hit and miss.
author: Bevin H.

description: Got here at 910, closing was 930 on a Sunday. Took a seat because nobody would acknowledge me and waited a good 5 minutes before someone decided to walk over and inform me that they are no longer taking orders. Lame.. I know it's Sunday night and everyone wants to bounce, but their business hours should reflect that
author: Ankur P.

description: Fine food but the experience I had with delivery was so bad That it knocks them to 2. The food came about 50 minutes late and the driver was so utterly rude. Wouldn't go again.
author: Noah S.

description: Best catfish al a carte ! If you like spicy this is the best place to come. Love it! Lost count how many times I've had it and I'm still not over it.
author: Dee J.

description: First time having dinner here at Zen Yai. Brought my little beagle terrier. Waitress was very cordial, my dog Augie is a service dog. Very impressed with the large menu. I chose the 3 item combo: shrimp pad tai, chicken curry rice small salad and fried won tons. Food came in ten minutes with ice water. Portions were good. Chicken curry had coconut sauce. Fried won tons were delicious. Shrimp Pad Thai was freshly cooked. I would come back with friends. Most dishes were in the 8 dollar range. A excellent deal if order alot of food.Bill was a little over nine dollars with tip 11 dollars. Brought left over Pad Thai for tommorow's lunch.
author: David D.

description: First experience with this place was actually the best delivery I've had in a while. The food was delivered in 35 minutes on a Saturday night and was fresh. The pad kee mao wasn't overly greasy (even as it cooled down a bit, it didn't get that slimy, oily feel that a lot of takeout has), the wontons were crispy, tasty, and bountiful--seriously, you get a ridiculous number of wontons--and the chicken satay was tender and juicy. I don't know that it'd be my go-to spot if I were going out for Thai, but it's solid takeout, especially for the price point. I'd order again in the future.
author: Laura B.

description:
This place is closest to my house, but it has the saddest, most boring curry ever. I got the yellow curry, and it was literally curry and chicken. No onions, no potatoes. Nothing. And the curry sauce itself was rather bland. Booooringgg....

I also recall getting their pad thai on another occasion, and it was mediocre at best.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
The dishes I have tried today are very much like those I have had in SE Asia.  Near San Francisco's Little Saigon I found many available tables at 6:30 Wednesday evening.  Zen Yai is known for three special little noodle bowls. Unfortunately that menu is written only in Thai and on boards hanging upon the wall. Fortunately, my server patiently described each bowl and the noodle options to me.
.
I tried the Tom Yom, dry/broth on the side, with fish balls, pork and liver on fine egg noodles. The contrasting flavors and textures make this one my favorite. If liver is not your thing; it sure wasn't mine, just pick it out, its liverness does not infect the whole bowl. Topped with fried chips. $3.50
.
Then I had the Thai boat (Yai) with wide rice noodles and beef. This was almost a soup with a very distinct flavor I cannot place, could be blood. This bowl was well spiced and topped with crunchy pork rines. $2.50
.
My last little bowl was the Yen ta 4 also with wide rice noodles and very well seasoned. What a great little melody of textures here. Fungus, fish balls, tiiiny squid, jellied blood (most likely a cows) lots of herbs all topped off with some crunchy fried dough/chip of some kind. $2.50
.
No beer or wine is served here. For my next visit I will try some BBQ and their curries.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Crab fried rice, boat noodle, and basically everything on the Thai menu are good

Unfortunately, there was a chipped piece of a plastic bowl in my fishcake.
author: Beef S.

description: Not the hippest spot on the block, but judging by the cliental of many Thai, it's one of the more authentic. Case in point, the yam woon sen, other than the size of the dish, and the mere fact you have to pay for it in USD, I bet most anyone would be hard-pressed to say this was made in America vs. some food cart on a Sukhumvit side alley in Bangkok. Their gai yang (BBQ chicken) is superb. I keep thinking they got lucky with the last batch but each time the chicken is just as tender. This place is also, interestingly enough, famous for its boat noodles. I actually never had these in Thailand when I lived there so I can't say for sure but judging from the sign (that's only in Thai writing) and the constant demand on these, I'd assume these are pretty legit. Lastly I have to mention their simple yet perfected khao man gai; be sure and liberally use the dipping sauce. Perhaps other items on the menu are not as good, but stick to the above and I guarantee you'll be happy (well other than your mouth being on fire if you aren't careful.)
author: Brian J.

description: Holy crap. The Zen Yai Tom Yum is amazing! I think it may have cured my head cold.
author: Kim C.

description: They're prices are really good compared to other Thai places, I've ordered from here twice.  Had the Pumpkin Curry which is great btw but I forgot that it's supposed to have shrimp as well because they only put ONE shrimp, one single piece of shrimp. That's pretty shady.
author: Naz M.

description: Dude I just grabbed some Thai iced tea but they were really nice and the drink was like $2. Support locals!
author: Air-ic Q.

description: A bit hit or miss, but if you order the right stuff you're in good shape. Their boat noodles (for whatever reason not listed on the menu) are great and should be your primary purpose for eating here. Flavorful, and with all the cracklins your soul desires. My friend and I went sort of overboard on the rest so I'll try to go through it quick. The fish choo-chee special was a tasty curry sauce dolloped fried fish that was a little over cooked. The green sea curry special was weirdly bland, and the bbq chicken curry was kinda mediocre and you'd probably be better served getting regular bbq chicken or regular chicken curry.
author: Misha T.

description:
Good food delivery when you're craving for Thai food. They are quite generous with the portion. I love their crab fried rice and their ribs. 

I've ordered several times and was never disappointed. 
Highly recommend this place.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Super affordable with good staff who sometimes slip up from being responsible for too many tables.

Quite authentic, and offers a variety of dishes that are hard to find like boat noodles and packaged snacks.
author: Brandon K.

description: My boyfriend and I have been wanting to try this place out for a while, today was the day. We got in around 8:15, the place wasn't as crowded. Plenty of tables still open. We sat down, the server was alright. We ordered the house boat noodle, pretty tasty with lots of spices. Second order we got was the fried tofu, it was alright. The peanut sauce it came with was tasty though.. then we shared a combo 2 which came with; yellow chicken curry, pad Thai and rice. That was pretty good, for $7.95 why not! My bf was definitely eating with his eyes when he ordered the sauté chicken stir fry with rice. Too bad he ordered it kind of spicy, not a big fan of spicy food lol. And of course I couldn't eat at a Thai restaurant without ordering a Thai ice tea! It was perfect, not too sweet nor too bland. The only thing I would complain about is on yelp, it shows it closes at 9 while.. at the restaurant it says 9... for thrown off by that.. couldn't even order another pad Thai to go, because of this. Next time, please change your timing on "yelp" to 9pm if you guys are closing at the that time. Overall good food, somewhat okay service. Would I recommend this? Yes if you want cheap authentic Thai food. Deserving 3 stars because the service needs to be worked on...
author: Stephanie Y.

description: The reason why I'm giving this place a star is for their customer service. I love their boat noodles here and it seems to be my go-to restaurant whenever I'm in town, but their customer service needs to be worked on. I get that it can get busy, but come on, following up with your customers after delivering their food to the table is just as important as taking our order. We asked for four water. It arrived. We then had to asked for straws to go with them. Three straws arrived. I'm not sure where the fourth straw was at? I ordered two large boat noodles, with fat noodles and requested it spicy. But when it came, they were with regular noodles instead and of course, not spicy at all. Instead of making it a big deal, my friend and I ate it anyways but shortly informed the guy who took our order that it was with fat noodles (chow fun) that we wanted. He stated he didn't hear me request that. Ok, I get that it is busy, but the waiter should have paid more attention to our order. I had to ask for additional broth because quite honestly, the boat noodles we've received didn't look like it was a "soup" dish at all. Myself and three other guests enjoyed our food, but where was the waiter(s) to check up on us or to see if we needed anything else? They were too busy helping other tables. Were we not important customers too? Not sure if it was because we had kids at the table with us but their customer service was very poor to the point where I didn't want to leave any tip at all, but I did. I ended up ordering two boat noodles to go. If the waiters had checked up on our table like they should, it would had been a better experience for me eating at this Thai restaurant. So I ended up going to the front counter to order my boat noodles. I said excuse me, can I order to go please? The other guy was like "hold just a moment ok". Like seriously, rude alright. I may not be of Thai descent but I can understand them talking. Good thing he didn't bad mouth to the other guy about me. The other guy that was next to him ended up taking my order anyways despite the other guy telling me that. I was annoyed by now. After my experience today, would I come back to this restaurant to eat? No, but I would order to go instead. Please train your employees right and have them work on their customer skills if you want your customers to have a pleasant dining experience!
author: Sally S.

description:
Been here a few times, and this week I was lucky to come two nights in a row.  Well, unlucky that I tried to go to another restaurant twice, but it was untimely closed twice, but I was happy to go to Zen Yai as an alternative.

The noodle soups here are delicious, and if you order the ones off their Thai menu on the wall, you can get three different  small bowls of noodle soup for 2.50 and 3.50 each.  The first is a traditional thai boat noodle with beef or pork.  (2.50)  It's really tasty and you can adjust the spice level.  Topped with fried pork skin, this was my favorite.  A rich and hearty soup, get it with wide rice noodles.  The other two soups were also delicious.  One was a thai sweet and sour soup with fish balls and other seafood ingredients topped with deep-fried wonton skins.  (3.50)  The last was a tom-yum type sound with ground pork and bbq pork.  This was my second favorite.  (3.50).  For the price and portions, consider it a noodle soup flight.  It will fill you up, and hey at these prices, add one more if you want!

The second night we tried rice plates.  The duck over rice was really good.  Boneless breast in a sweet soy sauce like glaze.  Yum.  What really got me was the special fried catfish deluxe.  Fried catfish in a curry sauce without coconut milk. IT WAS AMAZING!  Spicy!!! SPICY!!! SPICY!!! in a good way though.  One of my new favorite dishes in the city.  The catfish was fried perfectly with a  nice crust on it. The sauce was thick and coated everything, on the drier side, preserving the crunchiness of the catfish.

For the prices and the quality of food, this is one of the best thai places in the city. I like it when the menu is not the same old thai food!
author: Veasna H.

description: Is my favorite thai food in SF test is like thai food in bangkok i'm here everytime i'm on town
author: Yukarin T.

description: I was really excited over the boat noodles but they arent that flavorful. I ordered all four. The seafood one tastes really weird. Although I love how they are served in small bowls like that in Thai Land, it isnt good enough to get me to be a returning customer. 1 star for customer service, 1 star for setting, 1 star for food.
author: Jackson S.

description: Have you ever had Rad Na in Thailand, well it's so much better here.  Lao style papaya salad is on hit every time and be sure to pair it with Thai boat noodle.  Your taste buds will explode!
author: Aim B.

description: Delicious authentic Thai Boat Noodles. Superb Tom Yum Noodles soup. Authentic local Thai street food.
author: Max B. K.

description: I felt as if I were in Thailand when I visited this restaurant! 1000000% loved it! Everything tasted super good! Esp, the Thai Boat Noodles (A Must Try). Their service was fast, also the restaurant was clean. They indeed deserve a 5-star! Xx
author: Picha M.

description:
Love this place .. All of the food were great !
Yesterday, we've tried their Boat Noodle soup and all kind of their noodle style . Today we've tried Som-Tum and grill pork .... All of those, they were great I would include the services... You made our day gone better because we didn't find even ok services in Thai restaurant in San Francisco. 

Thanks for being so kind and very welcoming. We'd love to come back to Zen Yai again if we have a chance.     
 
San Diego folks
author: Yaifon P.

description:
I came here back in July 2016 & ordered to go. The Thai food here is a really good deal.  I ordered the pad thai with less oil & my brother got the thai fried rice with brown rice (he said it tasted pretty good). I love how sour the pad thai is even before I squeeze lime in it; the pad thai is on the sweet side, so if you like sweet pad thai, you'll like it here.   They give pretty good portions.  I was starving when I got there, so I ate the whole thing. But, on a normal occasion, the pad thai looked like it was enough for 1.5 meals.  

It's probably one of the cheapest places to get pad thai, along with Thai Basil in Berkeley (I haven't been there yet) and Million Thai (in SF on Taylor St.) with Groupon. It's around $8.25 (before tax). 

I'm giving 5 stars mainly because it's such a great deal (considering how hard it is to find cheap thai food these days in the Bay Area), the cashier was really nice, I love the ambiance & decor, the pad thai was really good & reasonably priced (though next time I'd probably ask for less sugar), they have brown rice and the portion was really filling. If I'm in Civic Center / Tenderloin, I'd definitely come back here!
author: Lena D.

description: This is by far the best Thai restaurant I've ever been to and believe me I've been to a lot of Thai restaurants in the Bay Area.  Basil chicken is my favorite dish.
author: Robert F.

description: We love love love this place especially their boat noodle! It is to die for! Their pad Thai, BBQ chicken with sticky rice and Thai fried rice are really great as well. On top of that service is always fast and friendly.
author: Tina N.

description:
Bestest, most authentic Thai restaurant in the whole city, maybe even the entire Bay Area.
My girlfriend and I are from Thailand, and we both love love love this place. 
I also recommend it to anyone who asks without hesitation. 

You can tell from tasting their dishes they're not really trying to "Americanize" their cooking for the general audience. Ask for more spicy and they'll make it *actually* spicy.

Their best dishes are on the Thai menus on the wall, but you really can't go wrong with anything you order here.

Here's a few favorites: (because there's too many!)
Boat Noodles (their most famous dish)
Other Noodles (you can customize to your heart's content)
Stir Fry Chinese Brocolli with Crispy Pork
Esan Sausage (Northeastern sausage)
Grilled Pork with Sticky Rice
Chicken over Rice (Kao Mun Gai)
Basil Duck

They also sell a variety of hard-to-find Thai desserts.
One recommendation would be "Kanom Tuay", which is a two-layered pudding, one layer is coconut, and another is pandan jelly. They come in small dish shaped pieces. Give it a try!
author: Nop J.

description:
The days of eating at OSHA is OVER.  This place rocks!  My fav Thai in SF.  Try the Mango salad and pineapple fried rice.  Yummmm.
Nothing fancy here - just good food.  Ambiance?  Are you here to eat or enjoy the view of Tenderloin?
author: John K.

description:
This place is soooo good. When you walk into a thai place and only see thai on the wall, you know you are in good hands.

We got something like mee poh, in small. It comes in pork/beef and flat/thin noodles, so you can do your own combo there. Super tasty. 

I was stupid so I ordered my default option, basil chicken, every time I walk into a new thai restaurant. Their basil chicken was as good as i expected. it was kinda watery and bland.

My friend order the pineapple fried rice and it was the best fried rice ever. I gave them extra point for the fried rice since they put raisin in it. 

We also got a couple dessert, the fried banana, sticky rice, and ice cream. The fried banana was super delicious!
author: Ruxin H.

description: Very good and authentic thai restaurant. Prices are cheap. Service is good and food is fresh
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description:
Seriously so bad. I don't know how I trusted these Yelp reviews. I ordered the pad see ew and the green curry fried rice to go. 

The pad see ew had 4 small pieces of broccoli and scant chicken. The rest was unappetizing, overly salted thick noodles.

The green curry fried rice was even worse as it's super dry and SO SPICY. It was literally like eating hot peppers. There wasn't really anything to it besides spicy rice.

I was stoked that the prices were so cheap and the takeout was ready in less than 15 minutes but the food is just not quality and makes my stomach uncomfortable. 

I live in the tender so I've eaten at quite a few Thai places. Let me just say I am not coming back here.
author: Connie W.

description: Love this place. Amazing, delicious, affordable Thai food. This place is no-frills (making it also fantastic for takeout). My staple TL Thai place.
author: Lara H.

description: All three dishes we had were excellent. Pad see ew, Pat Thai, barbecue chicken yellow curry.. The curry had lots of flavor depth.. YUM!  Service was fast. Prices very reasonable for San Francisco!
author: David L.

description: Authentic, affordable, and yummy Thai food! Gotta love the boat noodles!
author: Jasmine H.

description:
Service was better than the food. The famed Boat Noodles is rice noodles (thin or thick) in a soupy broth based dish that is on the salty side, was fairly "authentic". Not so sure Boat Noodles would appear in as many reviews if it was more widely known what the key ingredients are (there is animal blood in them thar noodles !). 

I'm also not so sure about some reviewers feeling of being mentally transported out of this gritty location when dining here, but perception is in the eye of the MSG saturated mind. Or, could it be that generally speaking, this location mentally transports people, as proven by the many mentally transported people which are regularly observable in this section of the 'Loin. This locale brings a hole new meaning to the Patsy Cline song "I'm CRAZY" for ....

Pad Thai lunch "special" w/ a mound of white rice and a dollop of iceberg lettuce salad, was o.k., green curry was a little strange with a large piece of dark meat chicken that should have been dissected before appearing on the table.

Accurate comments from another reviewer about a quality comparison (lower) than other "Thai" joints nearby, which is where I will eat "Thai" food, should I find myself incarcerated in this 'hood.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
They have a menu on the wall just in Thai but it is seriously delicious noodle soup.  I have no idea what it is, my Thai friend told me just to order it.  The other favorite is the Fresh rolls.  Rice noodle sheet wrapped around spring roll contents is a world of deliciousness...good riddance rice paper.

You can get it without shrimp to make it vegetarian. Their House Peanut Sauce is also the freshest, most delicious peanut sauce in the world, hands down!  

The bad news is that you might contract MRSA on the way to this joint in the TL and the service is just so so.  But the food is awesome!
author: Yue L.

description: Love Zen Yai, especially its famous both noodles. They serve the food fast. I don't have to wait that long.
author: Pavin C.

description: One of worst THAI meals I ever had! too much sauces, too much sugar, no flavor, limited spices. bad chef... hell FIND ANOTHER PLACE! This is the worst chinese inspired Thai food.
author: Evan C.

description: Food was delivered in approximately 30 minutes. My Pad See Eww was a bit overcooked but the Thai ice tea and fried rice were perfect!!  I would definitely order via Yelp again.
author: E. T.

description:
As mentioned in my tip, here are the must-order items:
* Boat noodle ($2.50/small bowl)
* Tom Yum noodle sans pork skin ($3.smth/small bowl)
* Fresh coconut juice 
* Thai iced tea
* Pad thai
* Duck larb
* Pumpkin curry (more pumpkin please!)

To-go friendly.
Fairly clean restrooms (separate per gender).
Cash&card.
Great service.
Speaking in Thai def. helps - they have a special menu.
Good for groups!
No parking lot, but free street parking after 6pm.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
More secret menus added. You would probably need a Thai companion to dine with you. My two most favorites include stir-fried Thai sukiyaki served on a sizzling plate and Thai chicken rice. 

People argue the true originality of chicken rice. Needless to say, Thai is my favorite. The rice is packed with chicken fat flavor and aroma of garlic, but what defines the dish is actually the sauce. The sauce is a mixture of soy sauce, fermented soybean sauce, lots of garlic, ginger and chillies. 

I guarantee the food here is very authentic. Boat noodles, Yen Ta Four and Tom Yum noodles are always available here.
author: Saran R.

description: Ordered Tom yum chicken soup, Tom yuk more like it. Spring rolls are good. Boyfriend ordered garlic pork, he said we won't be back. Disappointing when I had read good reviews. Soup taste very heavy on lime. No noodles,  obviously ordered wrong thing. I don't know,  very disappointing. Would never come back! Tony had terrible stomach problems all night. I just got cleaned out if you know what I mean. Sorry. Do not go here, you will be taking chances...
author: Kelly P.

description: I Still can't get over about a Bad service experience last night , We were accidentally Spilled a whole glass of water on the table and some on me , we were waiting and looking around for waiter and waitress to help us at least Offers a new set of spoon and plate No one show up for over an hour ( Moderate busy like 4-5 tables )but they just starring at us like Nothing ever happens my friend have to find a a small towel herself and I need to dry myself in Restroom while walking I almost fall over because of the water on the floor under our table even tho we waited for So long for them to dry out itself !!! I swear 4 servers were just walking around and stand at the counter watching us having a hard time !!!  We still have a good heart tips them 15% as a good San Franciscan !!
author: June S.

description:
Ordered delivery, and it arrived after 1.5 hour when the restaurant is located 6 min driving distance from my place. Portions are actually very small, and they went really cheap on my rice place - which is 80% rice and 20% toppings. I don't think this is how you should run the business. If I want rice, I'll order the freaking rice.

Note: The quality of the food is not bad for SF standard. 

P.S. If the delivery is delayed, please communicate this with your customer. Hungry people are not gonna be happy, but at least they will be understanding.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Pumpkin curry for the win!

Coworker and I decided to order delivery since it was raining cats and dogs on Fillmore. Good reviews, free delivery after $20, and cheap prices - we decided to bite the bullet and place an order 30 minutes before they closed after lunch. Couldn't be happier!

The curry was not spicy, and it was really soupy - just how I like it drenched over my rice. I would definitely order from here again!
author: Sabrina P.

description:
I have been there with friends several times. And everytime, I just ordered their combo , which is tasty and with different food options. I personally really like their thai iced tea and salad. The meal just costs around 11 bucks, which is not so expensive and worthy. 

Also, the environment is neat and clean. Good service as well. Definitely will come back !!!
author: Carmen L.

description:
Horrible experience with Zen Yai delivery via Yelp/delivery.com. Delivery took 1 hour 20 mins to arrive even though I ordered off peak hours (at 430pm) and was staying only a 10 min drive from the restaurant.

The Pad See Ew was incredibly bland (even though the fish cakes and soup tasted okay), and they even forgot the utensils!

Unreliable service and food quality- I feel cheated, especially since there are so many good options in SF.
author: Belinda N.

description:
So, I'm driving around with three business associates and we pass up like four Thai places
b/c we can't find parking and randomly happen
upon this place. So, we ordered the bottom noodles beef broth soup (delicious !!) seafood 
appetizer with calamari, shrimp friend thing
And some fried seafood roll ( pretty good )
So, yellow curry, red curry with chicken 
A minced chicken entree spicy and tofu with
vegetables
All was amazing !!
And we topped off with fried banana with vanilla
Ice cream to cool off the nice burn in our mouths
and fulfillment in our bellies
The damage $68 before tip
We all agreed that we hadn't eaten that for hot
$20 in a while
Only thing was they were busy and the boss lady
who served was short on food description .
Others servers made up for it.

Highly recommended
author: Tariq S.

description: Affordable, authentic Thai food and friendly staff.  All the qualities you want in a restaurant.  Came here with a Thai friend for her birthday and she ordered dishes I never would've ordered.  Got me out of my pad Thai, pumpkin curry comfort zone. Despite that, none of the dishes disappointed.  It's also a BYO kind of place with no corkage fee.  Can't argue with that.
author: Cristina B.

description:
Just ordered from them through Eat24 and I am thoroughly satisfied.  Adding them to my weekly lunch rotation.  Great portions, fair pricing, and great food; I can't complain.

Ps: if you are planning to use Eat24 for delivery, put in your order an hour before your lunch time.
author: Jen M.

description: Yummy Thai Taste! Zen Yai does not dissapoint, carrying Thai local menu with local Thai taste. The portion is american size alright, you can try Thai street food with premium quality ingredient here :)
author: Annie S.

description:
If you've tried or know anything about Thai boat noodle, then you'll also know that legit and authentic boat noodle is hard to come by in the Bay Area! First off, not many places serve it and secondly, the couple of places that do, are not up to par. The bloody broth needs to be the right thickness and saltiness--which most I've come across around here have been quite watery. I mean, I haven't been to Thailand or anything, but I've tried boat noodle from Thai town in LA and I have a good idea of what to expect. 

Anyway, the beau and I came across Zen Yai Thai during a food crawl one day and with their limited hours of business, we planned our day so that we were able to give them a try. Albeit the place is dingy and located in a sketchy area, but hey...they are only open during the day time anyway so don't be scurred!

For some odd reason, the menu they handed us did not include any boat noodle. We looked around on their walls and noticed that there was something written in another language (we're assuming Thai?), followed by $2.50. From reading the previous reviews we knew that the boat noodle was priced at $2.50, so we came to the conclusion that boat noodle was what was written on the wall. Lol...no clue how we were supposed to know! 

With that being said, we went with two small bowls of boat noodle, which were $2.50 each; large bowls were $6.95. We also went with one small bowl of yen fa to, which is the another noodle soup that is recognized for its distinct pink colored broth. The small was pretty tiny; you can finish it in a few scoops! It was perfect for our food crawl; however, if you're having a bowl as a meal, I'd get a large. The boat noodle broth was definitely on the saltier side, but it was legit and authentic. The broth was musky in a good way, with a hint of five spice--just as it should be! The yen fa to though, was overwhelmingly vinegary. The broth is typically sweet and flowery from the soybean paste, vinegar, and fish sauce, but for some reason it was drenched with vinegar here.

Most of the staff's English is broken, so there was definitely a little bit of a communication barrier. They were nice though. I'd come back for their boat noodle, if only they were open more hours!
author: Lien T.

description:
I've ordered from this restaurant several times in the past with exceptional results. The food was always flavorful, steaming hot, arrived in a timely manner and quite affordable. I honestly thought I had a go-to Thai place but... I ordered the Pad Thai (with shrimp), shrimp fried rice, BBQ pork, garlic chicken and egg rolls. I went to pull a piece of shrimp apart for a cat treat and it mushed in my fingers. Hmmm, I popped the other half in my mouth and immediately spit it out. The texture was creamy with a STRONG fish taste. Ok, one bad shrimp, no big deal but, they were all like that and the Pad Thai / Shrimp Fried Rice emitted a strong fish smell which, it should not have. All the shrimp had a strong odor and had a mushy consistency. CAN WE SAY SPOILED SHRIMP?

I called the restaurant to let them know that their shrimp had gone bad. I was trying to be nice but, was getting irritated trying to find other words for SPOILED because she had no idea what I was trying to say. She put me on hold and then came back insulted and demanding their shrimp was fresh! Give me name and phone number, we come pick it up." Never heard back from them, did get the refund for spoiled food from Grubhub. 

When someone is trying to be nice, don't cop an attitude because, had I not gotten this rectified it would have been Health Dept. time (an old employer in good standing with me). 

Sooo, love ya! BUH-BYE!
author: Jamilah A.

description: It looks like my search is over(for now), and it had ended in the TL. I've looked high and low in SF for authentic tasting Thai food, with a special focus on ACTUAL barbecue chicken (E-sarn style in particular) This place, in my opinion is the closest thing to what you'd find in actual Thailand (from my experience). BBQ chicken is closest, not exact, but closer than any other place I've tried. You can even order a whole chicken or half, with sticky rice. The Som Tum is good (Papaya salad can be ordered Thai style, with peanuts or E-sarn style without). Tod mun (Thai fish cakes) were tasty. My only complaint is that their pepper sauce/dip was not well put together, it was not spicy (No Thai chilis in it!?), pretty sure it was just some chili flakes, onion and fish sauce. Hmmm, that's not cutting it for me. I recommend this place if you want something more authentic, and not the strips of Grilled chicken breast meat most places try to call barbecue chicken. Finally, the service is "eh", but not rude, and the bill, well for SF, you will be pleased. Pictured (My order: Half bbq chicken, Som Tum, Tod Mun and a Coke). Next, I'll have the E-Sarn sausage and maybe grilled squid, and Khanom wan (sweets for dessert). Stay tuned! Overall a 3.5 star review.
author: R A.

description: Boat Noodle Soup just as it is in Bangkok, or any floating market in Thailand. It's served in small bowls, so order a few to start with ($2.50 each). Simply put - it is my favorite Thai soup. I usually order it with pork, but it comes with beef as well. Waitstaff is friendly, and service is efficient - always a pleasant experience!
author: James M.

description:
Now I know where to go for my boat noodle fix. I love how they have the small size bowl option and you can order as many small sizes of different varieties as you want till you're full. Just like in Thailand. Next time I'll have to let them know to make my orders less sweet. Everything I got came out on the sweeter side.

The Thai desserts they have in to-go containers are godsent. I grab a few (or half a dozen) on the way out so I'll have them to enjoy at home.
author: Yad L.

description:
It was my first time going to this place by my SF friend's recommendation. He told me that Thai style boat noodle is really famous here and I never heard of it and tried it before. So I was worried and nervous to try this food, so I ordered small bowl which is like only $3! When the food came out and tried, it had a new taste that I never tried it before. I recommend that you try it, if you never tried it before. Get the small one first because you might not like it. 

The reason I gave only 3 stars for this restaurant is that when we went there, the restaurant wasn't busy at all. I don't know what were the servers doing but they were so late taking our orders and bother asking how we are doing. Also, they were slow at everything except for the checks, which they took it right away when it was ready. Also, their silverwares were not even filled up for the next customers to use so we had to ask other tables for spoons. 

But their design of inside restaurant was good and clean.
author: Alice C.

description:
Been coming to Zen Yai for many years (at least once a week). The house noodle (Tom Yum) is amazing! It's the perfect comfort food for a Thai gal like myself. I also highly recommend their boat noodle.  The soup packs a lot of well-balanced flavors--leaving you wishing for more! 

Their specials are on the board written in Thai. One of the items is Congee (rice porridge), served only on Friday (10pm-1 am) and all day on Saturday and Sunday. Another authentic comfort dish! Must try! You won't be disappointed.
author: Teddie B.

description: This is the place for foodies who just want to try a small portion of everything. They have a thai menu on your left hand side when you walk in. The first menu are the Thai boat noodles, i tried all four of them and they are filled with herbs, spices, and seasonings which are my favoriate part of thai food. You can get them in big or small sizes. Small sizes are only 2.50-3.50 per bowl. The second menu are the porridge. They also have a variety of authentic dessert to choose from.
author: Lizi F.

description:
Horrible food for Thai restaurant! I have been so many Thai restaurant! This is the worst Thai food I have ever had. I ordered tom yum noodles soup, it didn't taste like tom yum noodle soup which had too much chilly sauce and too much oil on it. 

Not coming to this place.
author: Mei Y.

description:
Eek is right. Just moved a couple blocks from this place and from it's positive reviews on Yelp, I was hopeful it'd be my new Thai go to spot. Wherever I am living, I need at least 1, if not more, at hand at any time. The first time I got food here, it was very standard good thai - shared the fried wontons, green curry rice, and spicy noodle salad with a friend. All were okay, but would explore other options next time I came here. Very inexpensive though!m and nice staff Would probably have given 3 or 4 stars.

However, my second experience was so negative that I unfortunately will not be trying this place again. Ordered a couple things for lunch to share, and as I was digging into the crab fried rice, I heard a big crunch in my mouth. I thought, oh gross, was that an egg shell? But there was a crab claw in the rice so maybe I had gotten a piece of the shell. A few minutes later, digging around with a bit of a closer eye, I find a huge piece of egg shell. I pointed it out to my co-eating companions, and we all immediately lost our appetite and stopped eating. If something so obvious and gross happens twice in one meal, it just makes you think what else could be wrong in the lunch. Other people on the Eat24 website had made comments about egg shells in the rice, and I'm not sure why they're not more careful. I'm not the most squeamish diner, but thinking about eating something that rubbed against the inside of a chicken's butt made me nauseous immediately.

Bummed about the experience.
author: Sarah B.

description: One of my favorite place great food and good time for hang out with your friends. The best Thai noodle ever!
author: Aunggie N.

description:
I order for delivery meal and it was in my hotel in 30 min. The combo is really big so you need to be hungry...
The delivery guy forgot my drink so he went back to his restaurant and and bring me the drink.
It was Really nice. Thanks.
author: Laurène B.

description:
I used to order delivery from this place quite often.  I used to really like it, it was one of my go to places.  Tonight was the second time I've ordered from there this month and this time and last, the food was rather flavorless.  With being able to choose between "mild, medium, and hot", I would think that medium would have a good kick to it.  I gave this place another chance, because I have had good food here and hoped it was just an off night last time.  I picked medium spice for two dishes, they both arrived piping hot, which was good, but the spice level was zero, and the sauce in the dish had little to no flavor.  

I am very disappointed, will probably not order from here again.  Seems that food in the city is taking a downward dive, I haven't been having many good experiences with food.
author: Jason B.

description:
Oh why didn't I just stick to my regular radna?

I was starving with a bunch of friends looking for a great place to grab Thai food (of course trusting in my trusty ol Yelp). The service is great; everybody was so friendly and accommodating. I decided to start with my awesome blossom coconut milk based soup that is exactly how it should taste.

Then I went to try their Zen Yai Tom Yum noodle soup.... What was that? I asked for spicy and it was really just a toss in of flaky dried red pepper seeds. The soup was way too sweet. It was just a mesh of flavors that probably would've tasted great by itself but in combination, yikes. I took it togo which I knew was a no no. 

Well... my friends seemed to have enjoyed it more than me. Being that my boyfriend is Thai, I am utmost spoiled with amazing Thai food experiences. Poops. I'll order something else next time if I go here!
author: Mary C.

description:
I suppose it's best to stick to the dishes that came highly recommended by others yelpers unless you want to do the hit and miss method.

Looking at the star ratings I must be ordering the wrong dishes. I stopped here with the 'rents since they were craving Asian food. In the heart of the tenderloin neighborhood, even the staff at the information center says this area is the best place for some ethnic food. So I figured I couldn't go wrong. Boy was I wrong and so was the staff at the information center.

The service was super nice and friendly. Too bad they couldn't make up for the food. We ordered the BBQ pork in Thai style, red curry with chicken, veggie pad see ew, and pineapple fried rice. The curry and BBQ pork was decent but the other two dishes was just very disappointing. Also since we ordered the fried rice we didn't get any white rice which I found is really odd since you have to use some white rice to taste the curry flavor. We had to order a side order of white rice.
author: Jingwen Y.

description: Can't leave work to get lunch, so I've ordered delivery a few times already and haven't been disappointed. Food is delicious and price is great! The entrance to my job is a bit tricky, but the staff manages to find it no problem! As a matter of fact, I'm going to order something right now :D
author: Jenn H.

description:
We came here because we were searching for KaSoy and found that boat noodles were the closest thing that they had in the city.  I was a bit confused when I came here because they didn't have it on the actual menu, but I figured it was written in Thai on the wall.
