We ordered the Beef and Pork boat noodles, and both were amazing.  I just didn't expect the small to be that small, so we ordered another bowl in large.  The noodles was defiantly good, but I felt like I got knocked out by MSG after.
author: Lynn L.

description:
The BOAT NOODLE: What makes Zen Yai unique is that their food is not diluted or simplified for the American palette and their signature "Boat Noodles" is exemplary of the flavor and heat that their Thai dishes bring to the table. 

The BRINK OF PERSPIRATION: There's something about this place that makes you feel like you're not in the Tenderloin anymore; perhaps it's the carved wood column or the blackboards of specials written entirely in Thai. In any case, the owners seem comfortable enough in their skin to say, "Yea I know you've had Thai food before, but this is how we like to do things."

Enter the "Boat Noodle", a curiously small bowl of rice noodles in a dark broth topped with slices of meat, meatballs, pork rinds (?), spices and chilies. It's an eclectic mixture of textures and provides just enough heat to take you to the brink of perspiration. It's like an appetizer small enough to be handheld, but still makes a bold statement. The draw is that it's inexpensive, so you can also try other noodle soups too. 

Here's my tip: when given a choice of 1) vermicelli, 2) medium and 3) thick rice noodle, the correct answer is 2) medium. Medium thickness has just the right chewiness while balancing out the rich and spicy broth. Vermicelli is super thin and only gets drowned without a life-preserver to save it.

Let's also remember that Zen Yai also makes Thai classics. The creamy Tom Kha is a rich and savory coconut soup with veggies and lemongrass that swirl to the rhythm of your ladle. This can be easily paired with white rice or consumed on its own.

The BBQ pork remind me of the Vietnamese version, generously marinaded in fish sauce, thinly cut and cooked with grill marks and a nice glisten. 

Admittedly, the papaya salad was a bit plain and didn't have as much character as the other dishes. Simply, papaya and fish sauce. I wish it had more pickles and roasted peanuts to keep as company.

Come because it's unique. Stay because of its warm, family-friendly atmosphere and courteous staff.
author: Robin H.

description:
I came here because I wanted to try to boat noodle! my boyfriend is Thai and he's been to different thai restaurants that serve boat noodle, but none of them are as authentic as this place! for only $2.50 you're able to get a small bowl! 

the boat noodle isn't on the menu, but it's written in Thai on the blackboard they have inside the restaurant. I also saw that they posted a sign on the wall promoting the boat noodle in English! 

you're able to choose from beef or pork. I got a small bowl of the beef boat noodle and it was so good! to be honest, I was always afraid to try it whenever my boyfriend would eat it because of what they use to make the broth. I've become more open to trying different things and I'm glad because these noodles were the bomb! one small bowl was enough for me, but my boyfriend got 2 small bowls: 1 pork and 1 beef. he said the beef is more flavorful than the pork flavored one. 

I'd definitely recommend getting the beef boat noodle. something about eating it in a small portion makes it taste so good. 

we're definitely coming back for the boat noodle. I want to try their other thai dishes as well!
author: Callie L.

description: The boat noodles are interesting but not necessarily outstanding.  They are overly salted & for the price, you can grab something much tastier in this area.
author: Adam X.

description:
Working in the area again today, my co-workers recommended Zen Yai Thai for lunch.  We arrived at 12:45pm and the restaurant was full, but diners at three tables were paying so our wait was not long.

After ordering our Thai ice coffee (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zen-yai-thai-restaurant-san-francisco?select=5ZSxOdoWA43cq8FygAqgiw#5ZSxOdoWA43cq8FygAqgiw), we placed our orders.  My two co-worker ordered their favorite dish, spicy calamari with rice.  I love Thai fried rice and decided to order the pineapple fried rice (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zen-yai-thai-restaurant-san-francisco?select=5ZSxOdoWA43cq8FygAqgiw#HC38h5Yg18u_Mu4BXeV9Gw), which consisted of shrimp, chicken, pineapple, cashews, raisins and tomatoes.  The dish was tasty with the combination of the ingredients and the scrambled eggs and sliced onions in it.  The dish only had two SMALL shrimps in it.  Given the size of the shrimp, they should have had four in the dish.  

Overall, food was good and service was fast, friendly and efficient.  Didn't get to read Yelp reviews beforehand, but it seems the Boat Noodles are a must have here.  Will be back to try them at my next visit.
author: Al L.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF because of the authentic taste. My favorite menu is thai boat noodle, Tom Yam noodle, Pork with garlic over rice, and Pork with Thai basil over rice.
author: Pat K.

description:
My friend I can come by last night after a show at GAMH.
The food was yummy and the price was great! Four plates come to about roughly $40 for the both of us! If we are in the area we will be coming back here!
author: Maria Pilar M.

description:
I had been wanting to try Thai Boat Noodles ever since they appeared in the Fung Bros.' Asian Noodle Soups! video and found this place.  Thanks, Yelpers! 

The noodles are in the Thai-language menu on the wall, and not in the printed menu. My lunch buddy chickened out after reading online about what the broth is made of, too bad for her.  What a flavorful dish, and cheap and filling.  Admittedly, the Tenderloin isn't the best neighborhood, but it is worth coming out here to eat. 

My friend who did not get to try the boat noodles had good things to say about the red duck curry.
author: Elaine S.

description:
My bf and I were in Thailand this summer so we know a bit about what to expect at a Thai restaurant now. This is it - seriously took us back! 

We had the boat noodles to start which had great flavor. We also had the green papaya salad which was ok but warning! It is insanely spicy!!!! 

Then we had pad see ew with chicken which was great and duck with friend basil which was ok - would have preferred chicken I think. 

Dessert was of course mango with coconut sticky rice which seriously brought us back to Bangkok! So so good! 

Service was quick and friendly too.
author: Becca W.

description: The boat noodles are so yummy and delicious. It's my new craving. Worth a trek from the East Bay.
author: Mahri B.

description:
We were referred by a Thai friend so I was expecting very good. I had the Spicy Chicken Combo, and it was very good, however no Singha Beer available 
My wife had the gut-the-ow, and she said the noodles were not cooked enough. Their desserts are tasty though.
author: LB B.

description: One of my new favorite Thai restaurants. The Thai Boat Noodles are so great, and at $2.50 for a small bowl you can just keep piling them up until you're full.
author: Daniel H.

description:
This is my go to place for getting my fixation of boat noodles. The boat noodle menus are in Thai only. Essentially, you have 4 types of boat noodle varieties:
1. Tom Yau boat noodle
2. Yen Tau Fu ( seafood boat noodle with red bean soup)
3. Beef boat Noodle
4. Pork boat Noodle 
It come in large size & small size, I usually order 4 of those varieties in small!
I haven't try other dishes, but I do not think I can order other dishes, as the boat noodles are way too addictive!
author: Dan A.

description:
I feel the need to write a novel, sorry.

I went with my friend and my boyfriend and the service was meh, the food was absolutely gross. We were hungry but we quickly lost our appetites halfway through eating. Not knowing that the boat noodles were supposedly the greatest thing to order here- 

I ordered a papaya salad, and spicy chicken eggplant. Halfway through eating, I had a stomach ache. In fact, we all did. 

My friend ordered a roast duck pineapple fried rice (she substituted it over shrimp for 4 dollars.), and my boyfriend had the combination fried rice. 

My salad was mediocre. It wasn't bad, probably out of everything we had.. 
But still.


I received my food before anyone else and waited for a little bit, but when I started eating- the food was kinda lukewarm/cold, and tasted off to me. My boyfriend had half cooked squid and really disgusting chicken in his friend rice.

I think the worst part was when my friend waited the longest for her pineapple duck fried rice and the duck was for sure spoiled + there was so much onion that it probably took up 1/4 of the dish. there were 5 really tiny pieces of duck... For 4 dollars. We asked a waiter for hot sauce twice and he was busy talking to other girls at a table and forgot about us.

I understand that the boat noodles are the main reason why everyone comes here but seriously? I don't think I even want to come back even if those boat noodles were good.
author: Deanna T.

description: I've dined here before and decided to have delivery service. The food does not disappoint! Everything tasty and ordered for a party of 5. Only down side was not enough utensils for all and with 2 curry dishes, they should have at least put in a couple of spoons for options to eat with. Once you're in a hotel room, you have nothing to supplement eating with. They should overlook the orders and make sure there is enough utensils! Still very delicious!
author: Cory H.

description: Pad Thai had only 2 shrimp and 2 pieces of chicken, but flavors were good. Medium spice had a tasty flavor and little spice. The yellow chicken curry was definitely tasty. I'd go back, although 1.5 hrs for delivery is a bit much. You are better off ordering for take out. Overall the portions are worth it and so is the pricing.
author: Peanuts M.

description: Ordered more than 90 minutes ago and so I look out my apartment window and the driver is chatting away on his phone with my order in his hand. So I watch him and for about 3 minutes just sits there. I yell down "yo is that my order?" Sure enough it is. Dude seriously wtf?! Food is cold when I start eating. I'm a pretty good tipper but this place no longer gets the benefit of the doubt in my mind. It's been like this for a long time but this last stunt is just stooooopid. Jokers.
author: Emmett K.

description:
Come here for one thing....DRAGON BOAT NOODLES.

1 - Yes, only written on the chalkboard (kinda like a secret menu)
2 - BOMBBBBBBB flavors. I've never had anything like it at a Thai restaurant. The ingredients are so authentic. Reminds me of a bowl of soup that my mom would make for me. AND I'm not even Thai!!!!!!
3 - Order small bowls! That way, you can order different kinds! I'd tell you what I ordered...but my Thai friend ordered for me.

I crave this seriously every day of my life now. Thanks a lot Zen Yai!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Disappointed. I ordered delivery on a Sunday evening. Took longer than estimated. Food was cold. The taste was bland. All and all, not a good experience. There are better Thai options in the area.
author: Michael D.

description:
I only go there for boat noodle. They have the best soup base. Cheap and great meal for a cold day. When you ask for spicy, it's thai spicy. They don't do farang spicy :-p 

I typically give thumb down if I see broccoli on the Asian dishes and won't order them at all. But I'll try other dishes next time. The four stars are for the boat noodle and friendly service.
author: Blackwidow K.

description: Spot on, delicious and cheap that food.  I have never had a bad meal here or been disappointed. Staff is friendly and fast. You cannot go wrong
author: Jonathan B.

description: Cheap but so delicious! I always order my favorite: BBQ pork over rice. It's good for both breakfast or late night snacks!
author: Reyner T.

description:
I've been in a bit of a food slump at work. I usually bring food but on some days it just doesn't work out and I want to go somewhere with good food, but not my usual places. You could easily fall into a Tropisueno food rut at my office since it's right across the street. I happened to come across the Great Noodle Quest in SF Magazine and used that to bookmark some new places to try (http://www.modernluxury.com/san-francisco/story/the-great-noodle-quest?page=4). Zen Yai Thai is pretty close - or at least close enough to zoom there and back on my bike without the noodles getting cold.

NOTE: Though there is a sign on the wall saying "boat noodles $2.50" apparently this small order only applies to eat in orders. If you get take-away like I did you can only get the large order of boat noodles for $6.95 + tax. -1 star for this bit of tomfoolery.

So how were the noodles? Nope, I couldn't taste the blood in the sauce. Yes, they were scrumptious. Thin rice noodles with sliced pork, pork meatballs, crisp fried pork rind all sloshing around in a rich spicy broth. Nom nom. Even though they give you enough broth to make you think it's an actual broth you should really think of it as a sauce. Slurp it up with the noodles but don't attempt to drink it afterwards. It's thick and rich, not for sipping. For more info on the noodles - http://blogs.sfweekly.com/foodie/2012/06/boat_noodles_and_secret_menu_a.php.
author: Jean K.

description:
STAY AWAY!!!!!

Placed my order via EAT24, paid in FULL by PayPal; 60 mins later, the delivery guy arrived my front desk and by the time I walked down, HE LEFT!!!!!! I called the restaurant and all they told me is to wait, not their fault because I didn't pay (well obviously I paid in full online with the receipt in hand), so I ended up waiting another 60 mins for the delivery guy to come pick with my food COLD. 

I do not like honest restaurant and def do not enough eating cold Thai food. Unless that's what you looking for, stay away! I would order from other Thai place next time.
author: Hunter S.

description: Went there for the "Boat Noodle Soups".  These are the soups listed in Thai on the wall (not on the menu and not written in English).  We got the small bowls so we could order 4 of them.  We tried the pork, beef, and seafood.  Everyone at the table liked the pork one the best so we ordered another pork as our 4th bowl.  This style of soup is not widely available so we drove all the way from the south bay to get it.  It was worth the drive.
author: Lily L.

description: I have eaten at this place a couple of times before and the best dishes are the bbq meat and fried rice. I ordered takeout today and the pad kee Mao lacked flavor and was not spicy at all (I had requested for spicy). It really was the worst pad kee Mao I've ever had in my life. The bbq chicken over fried rice was better but a tad too sweet. The boat noodle was not tasty in my opinion. The serving size for everything was good but the taste was just not there. I've had better.
author: Pana P.

description:
After seeing so many great reviews, decided to come here for a bowl of thai boat noodles. There's a menu on the wall in Thai (not on the written English menu). 

I ordered the pork boat noodles, spicy. Large was 6.95 and small was 2.50 -- since I was hungry I opted for the large. 
From pictures, it looks like the small is half the size of the large so it would have made more sense to order 2 smells instead of 1 large! 

Anyway, the bowl was yummy -- broth was flavorful and had just the right amount of spice. Next time I will try the beef boat noodles, and perhaps will do 2 orders of the small. 

All in all a great cheap meal with friendly fast service.
author: Siv L.

description: We came here for dinner and it was empty. That should have been a red flag. The portions were on the small side, crap service, and tastless food? Never again..
author: Marina K.

description:
My friend suggested Zen Yai for a Wednesday dinner after reading about it in SF Weekly. Zen Yai is your stereotypical Tenderloin Asian restaurant, straddling the border of sanitary and dirty. The menu is pretty extensive and includes the usual staple Thai dishes (Pad Thai, Pad See Ew, etc).

We bought a box of Sa Koo Sai Moo ($5), which are ground pork tapioca dumplings, as an appetizer. This was not on the menu - you have to go to the counter in the back (cash only, but regular sit-down food takes card). There's an assortment of other appetizer-sized items in to-go containers here as well.

The real draw at Zen Yai is the Boat Noodles ($2.50/small, $6.95/large). They aren't on the menu, but there's a paper sign on the wall noting their existence, as well as a chalkboard entirely written in Thai with pricing that matches. The broth is made with blood, which sounds unappetizing, but it's flavored with copious amounts of Thai herbs and spices. You can choose between 4 types of noodles (flat wide, clear, egg, and another option) and beef/pork. If you don't like spicy food, make sure to ask them to tone down the spice level. This was my first time trying boat noodles, and usually Asian blood-containing dishes make me queasy, but these noodles were richly flavorful and delicious. I shared a large with my friend, which was a good amount because I think a large bowl on my own would have been overkill.

We also shared the Duck Noodle Soup ($7.95). I love Thai duck noodle soup, but the broth is usually fatty/heavy and leaves me feeling lethargic/bloated from the salt. But then Zen Yai happened - it retains the rich flavor of duck broth and juicy meat, but did not leave me regretting all my life choices. I did not drink a gallon of water when I got home, either.

To polish off the meal, I got a Thai Iced Tea ($2). Nothing too special or detracting here.

Zen Yai is an authentic and very reasonably-priced Thai food experience. It didn't get too busy for dinner, and the waitress was very kind and explained parts of the menu for us. I would highly recommend trying this place if you're looking for a different spin on Thai food!
author: Jessica F.

description: Bless your hearts for having egg fried rice and yummy yellow curry! Had food delivered and my tummy is very happy :)
author: Junalyn L.

description: One of the best authentic Thai restaurant in San Francisco!
author: Jane J.

description:
Don't get me wrong. I just don't get t why people like it here. Authentic Thai food? Ehh..maybe because all of people working there are Thais. Ehh..maybe they have so many choice of Thai menus. But listen up..I've had it better. This place is not really clean, like the hole in the wall. 
Service = Meh..not attentive AT ALL. Thai style? I don't know. They talked a lot each other and for got about customers. Most customers are Thais by the way. 
Food = small portion like you get what you pay. Got some flavor but not tasty like I expected. 
I might not come back again. There are so many Thai restaurants in SF if you crave Thai food.
author: Manisa K.

description: Worst service ever. We are still waiting on our order it's been over an hour and a half. Completely disappointed. We called the restaurant to see about our order since it had been 1 hour at this time, she told us, "Uhh ten min or uhhh ten minutes ya, thank you for waiting have good night", and hung up. Called back 15 minutes later, "Hold on", and never comes back to the phone, she left the phone we could hear her talking in background and we hung up after 5 minutes and now it has a busy tone. We are NOT accepting the food. This is happening now. 3/23/16, 8:35pm, 7pm we ordered.
author: Christopher J.

description: Would have given 4 stars if it wasn't for the awful service. I was craving their popular boat noodles so I called to order for delivery and the lady on the phone was rude. In addition, it took them an hour and a half for delivery nearby. Other than the service, the boat noodles tasted amazing.
author: Joyce C.

description:
Lima bintang. Plus one, for accommodating the duck larb request.
Awesome Tom Yum. Try the small size first with thin noodle. Noodles are perfectly chewy and compliment the complex broth. Opt out of the liver if it's not your thing.
author: Geordie E.

description: This place was delicious, affordable had great service and large portions. If you're in the tenderloin it's worth your time!
author: Christopher A.

description: Excellent restaurant for really delicious Thai food. Considering that it is located in the middle of San Francisco the value for money is just excellent! The Pad Thai is great!
author: Stefan H.

description:
Arguably the best and most authentic Thai restaurant in the SF / Bay Area.  I have traveled Thailand extensively, and the minute I walked through the door, I felt like I was back in Bangkok.  Everything was exceptional, and my Thai wife was in heaven.  We have a new #1 Thai restaurant... sorry Bronze Buddha in Concord, but you are #2.  

There are two negatives:  1) the area the restaurant is in (Tenderloin) is very sketchy, with homeless people on every corner.  2) they don't serve alcohol, which for me is tough.
author: Jay K.

description:
Awesome boat noodle soup, better than I had in Thailand. 

Thick broth, proper thin rice noodles, plenty of veg, meatballs and tender beef, with a bit of pork cracklings to boot.

This is the old Racha Thai location, and they still serve the Racha Thai sauteed calamari I had frequently when I was a kid. That dish totally brought me back.
author: Derrick V.

description: I came here twice during my visit to the Golden City. I tried Kao Moo Dang, Tom Yum Noodle, Pork and Beef boat noodles, Papaya Salad both Laos and Thai styles. I almost cried after the first bite coz it was frickin spicy, no no no Im kidding. I almost cried because it was REAL THAI FOOD!!!  I've been living in the states almost 5 years and this place makes the best I ever had Thai food in America. I want to give you a heads-up, though. This place is not for you if you know only Tom Kha or Pad Thai. On the other words, if you're a rookie for Thai cuisine. I was kinda upset when I saw only 3 and a half stars for this place. This place has delicious Thai food and super affordable.
author: Patty N.

description: I've been here every times when I come to SF..and still my number one choice when I'm craving for Thai Food. I love it when I ask for extra spicy and I get crazy spicy!!! Keep it up guys...Good Job!!
author: May M.

description: This place is increasingly substituting out all meat for pieces of bone, fat, and whatever else constituted the animal.  I think today's curry--which is incredibly flavorful--had *maybe* two bites of actual chicken meat.  After spending my entire meal anxious I'd choke on one of the several small bone fragments sprinkled in the curry, I decided to finally stop going to Zen Thai.  I've always noticed they were stingy on whatever meat you ordered, and now it's gotten to the point that it's just a joke.  Do they have only one chicken that must be shared among all of their customers, like some impoverished village?
author: Adam S.

description: Came back from a freezing football game and I knew I needed soup. Ordered from Eat24 on the ride over to my house. The delivery guy showed up 5 minutes after I got home. So clutch. The Zen Yai Tom Yum soup came with the noodles and bean sprouts separately so it wouldn't get soggy. The soup was so flavorful and delicious. Seriously giving me life. I ordered pad see ew and pineapple fried rice but the soup was so filling I couldn't eat the other dishes. No worries, I'll save them for dinner. Will definitely order from them again!
author: Melissa T.

description:
The boyfriend and I were trying really hard not to melt, so we decided to not go outside for dinner. This meant it was the perfect time to try out a new delivery place. I vetoed his usual Thai place (since their prices rose substantially and they had a $3 delivery fee) and voted for Zen Yai since it came up on my Eat24 with some pretty excellent ratings and free delivery.

Hoh my goodness. This was definitely a good idea. The food is nice and cheap, but more importantly, it's so damn tasty. For the quantity and quality I got, I would have expected to pay $12-$15 per dish at any other Thai restaurant - but their entrees cost about $8-$10 at most. Boyfriend got the crab fried rice (extra tasty and had such yummy crab...complete with a crab leg or two as well) and I got the chicken and eggplant. We also got a side of chicken satay, because I always judge Thai places by their chicken satay.

Now, the boyfriend usually harbors a great dislike for chicken satay. More often than not, it's dry, and the peanut sauce doesn't do much to help it (note: I like my chicken dry, okay. It's like having chicken jerky). Zen Yai's chicken satay actually surprised him and he said that it was probably the best chicken satay he's ever had, because it was juicy and flavorful, and the peanut sauce, while sweeter than I'm used to, somehow went along beautifully with it. Oh yes.

My chicken and eggplant over white rice was delicious as well. I didn't even mind that I had to order the rice separately, because my meal was still basically $10 and was still good for two meals. It had one of those slow burns, and I would totally get this if I were feeling sick and wanted to clear up my sinuses, since there were lots of jalapenos as well.

We have found our go-to Thai delivery place. This marks three whole go-to delivery restaurants. Aw yiss!
author: Robbin A.

description: The Best Boat Noodle Bowl in the Bay Area!
author: Wan T.

description:
Tom Yum Noodle Soup Special was incredibly delicious. This is the best Tom Yum noodle soup i've had in years.

The thinly sliced liver, minced pork, and tangy-limey broth were phenomenal mix. It was $8.65. 

AREA:
It's in a slightly shady area. Recommendation : Sit as far into the restaurant as you can. I saw a homeless lady rush into the restaurant and was just being a bit loud to a customer sitting near the front door. She left very quickly, but just to be safe - sit near the inside closer to the kitchen.

Will definitely be coming back here as soon as I can to try other items. Potentially one of my favorite places in SF now.
author: Vi T.

description:
I was a little overwhelmed with the questions that came with ordering the off-menu boat noodles.  Small for $2.50, or a full order for $6.95?  Pork or beef? Choice of 4 types of noodles (ho fun, thin rice noodle, clear noodle, some that sounds like "special" noodle)?  Spiciness level?  The waitress said it so fast, my friend just sat in a daze and had to ask again.  The noodles are great, though.  Really rich and flavorful.

As for the other dishes, the chicken larb was good, though pretty spicy considering it was supposed to be mild.  I've also had the curry catfish, which was delicious.  It's basically a good Thai place, with a standout dish in the boat noodles.

Service was friendly and attentive and the place is pretty clean.  Of course, this is in the Tenderloin so you have to be careful outside.
author: C. C.

description:
Worst Thai food I ever had. Pus, waiting 1.5 hours for delivery is not cool !
And if you're going to replace my fresh spring rolls with cheaper fried ones, at least have decency to add more than 3 of them.
SO NOT WORTH THE MONEY!
author: ananya y.

description: The spring rolls are on point !! The combo number two was every eventful. But the tom kha was funny tasting, tangy but milky coconut. Maybe it's supposed to taste that way, I wasn't a fan. I was just trying out a new food.
author: Cyndi D.

description: The food tasted old/not fresh. The rice had a strange consistency. The papaya salad was limp. Overall, I would not go here again.
author: Navin G.

description: This is my first and last time at this restaurant. The food was horrible. Noodle soup was super cold. Rice was dry and hard. Papaya salad was not so appetize (seem like they made it for so long. I order porridge for kids. It was many big chunk of rice like a ball and watery soup plus it was cold. Rice with bbq pork (kaw moo-dang) I got only fat part on bbq pork. Fried banana was very soft and very small piece of banana & batter so thick. Service just ok Truly disappointed on the food.
author: Rara A.

description: Unequivocally the best Thai boat noodles in America. It tastes almost identical to what you get in Thailand. Highly recommend
author: Saeed N.

description:
I'd give them 5 stars for take-out and 3 stars for dining in.  

First off, the food---SO good, especially the BBQ.  Order off that part of the menu and it's a home run.  The curries are also great.  In fact, everything I've ordered from delivery is solid.  They say 1.5 to 2 hours for delivery but it is more like 1 to 1.5 hours and worth the wait.  

Last night I went to eat there.  I had the boat noodle soup....blah.  It was a bowl of what looked like a bunch of left overs or morning after vomit.  The portion was insultingly small (half a bowl at the most and the bowl was small) and had an unremarkable flavor.  Avoid it.  I seriously can't imagine why others on here say it's good.  Total crap.  I also had one of their fish specials.  Nothing was bad about it but nothing stood out either....average.  Think a lightly fried filet with a splash of curry sauce ladled on it with a side of white rice and tired dry steamed broccoli. Why this is listed as a chef's special is beyond me.  The mango rice for desert was great!  Get it.  

The service is a little off.  Yes, they are very sweet and nice.  But, get things right.  I ordered my food and said I was very thirsty yet the waitress never brought my water.  I waited as other tables who had ordered got their drinks so I went to the counter and got it.  Beyond that, all they do is drop off the food and run off before you can say thank you and/or ask for anything else.  I also had several servers and they seemed confused.  They were not full either.  

The interior is fine...a little funky and worn as one would expect in the neighborhood.  I kind of liked that it was more authentic "mom and pop."  

Will I give it another try?  Yes for delivery: BBQ or curries.  If there were not so many other solid Thai places within a few blocks I'd go back but think I'll try others first if I am in the mood to eat in.   

Seriously, get their BBQ ribs!  SOOOO GOOD!
author: John B.

description:
This place is very authentic and delicious. The people who work here are sweet as they come. Do not judge based on the neighborhood. It's a gem and according to all my dear southeast asian friends...real deal. 
Yummy....making myself hungry.

Tod mun 
Satay 
Pad Grapow 
All Soups 
All curries....
Go there and enjoy!
p.s. OPEN LATE NIGHT!
author: Darina N.

description:
The yellow curry marked as vegetarian actually has shrimp sauce in it.

How do I know?

My hives told me.
author: Jenny U.

description:
when walked in it was like a hole in the wall kind of place. 
all the staff speaks thai. english was ok at least they can understand. 
i ordered the thai spicy calamari  stir fry for only 7.95. which i thought was cheaper than other thai spots in sf. 
the portion of the plate was kinda small not enough rice. there were lots of bamboo in it more than the calamari. i ordered thai spicy and it wasnt even that hot. i do love the lil spice tray they have tho. 
i think its like you pay what you get. 
the staff were attentive  and refilled my water. 
but they do talk alot to each other.
author: Alex T.

description: love their thai food, portion is great, the food taste delicious and packed with flavor.
author: Tri N.

description: My gf and I came to San Francisco for a quick get away, and we found this place through Yelp (thanks Yelp for always coming though). The food is delicious. The service is fast and friendly, and the prices are very affordable, seeing as how everything in SF is ridiculously priced. But it's SF what do we expect it's expensive to live or even visit here from out of town but anyways this Thai place definitely came through.
author: Frank P.

description:
I saw that majority of the reviews here raved about the boat noodles. So boat noodles was the reason I came here. It's also the reason it failed my expectations.

My bar was relatively high because Lers Ros Tenderloin makes pretty good boat noodles.  Here, I ordered the beef boat noodle soup () and a dry yen ta fo noodle (). However, the boat noodle soup was not very thick and herb-y. It was also too sweet. The meatball tasted more like it was made of pork with fillings than beef.  Yen ta fo was also just okay. Ingredients are a little wanting. No organ meat and no seafood (aside from some fishcake).

I admit that it's nice that this place offers Thai dessert, snacks, tapioca dumpling (), dry sukiyaki (), etc, that are very difficult to come by in this area. It's also a plus that they offer small bowl sizes. I might come back again for those.

But for boat noodles alone, I might have given it four stars if it were located in an area that doesn't serve boat noodles. But c'mon, you must at least be as good as your competition less than a block away to get four stars.  Not only is Lers Ros's boat noodle (or kuay jub ()) better, its dry tom yum rice noodle () also beats the dry noodle I had here.
author: pH R.

description:
Zen Yai is STILL my favorite place in the area for lunch when I'm craving Thai!

During my most recent visit I also tried a bowl of the pork boat noodles (in addition to my normal Combo B). Also a great value, a small bowl is only $2.50. You will want to order something else along with it or a second bowl because a small is truly a small. But overall, the dish was full of flavor. Be forewarned, it is on the spicy side. I think on my next visit I will forego my normal combo B and try a bowl of the beef noodles and a cup of the Tom gai soup. I'll be sure to let y'all know how it goes!

Also a note on the yellow chicken curry in my combo B:  The chicken curry was creamy and the chunks of chicken were large and tender!

No complaints about  the service either.  Very nice and accommodating folks running the show.
author: Matt S.

description:
Wow very surprised by all the negative service reviews, but despite people's warnings, I decided to be my own judge. Found free time to come by with my boyfriend after seeing a friend's instagram picture. I love to eat thai food and was pleasantly surprised that I haven't seen all there is to offer. I've never heard of boat noodles until I saw the post. 

Parking was a breeze to find on a Saturday afternoon. We walked in and was promptly greeted and seated by the waitress. I skimmed through the menu and searched for any item that stood out to me. I sadly relied on pictures of the boat noodles on my mobile app as I ordered to make sure I was ordering the correct one. The small boat noodles ($2.50) is offered in thick or thin rice noodles. You may choose from beef or pork. I believe there's also another option. The bf and I ordered one of each plus a plate of crab fried rice ($7.95). The noodles were first to arrive. There's probably a good 5 bites worth of noodles, but definitely no more than that. A few semi meatballs and one piece of whichever meat you choose. I loved the pieces of pork rind for both orders, adds a nice crunch to the meal. The broth was interesting! In my opinion, it tasted like 5 spice seasoning with a hint of palm sugar. It was full of garlic flavor and even chili peppers. Unfortunately, I inhaled as I slurped the soup and lodged a chili pepper into my throat as I choked. Felt like my throat was disentegrating as I gasped for water and air. Even with that experience, there was no doubt in my mind that I would still finish the broth, because yes, it's that good even when your throat is on fire. The crab fried rice was also delicious. They were generous with the crabmeat. 

The service was very attentive. In fact, after paying for the bill, they have dessert for take-out laid along the counter to purchase. The man at the counter recommended a few for me and I appreciated the attention:D

Its 11:30pm now, had this today for lunch and I'm almost contemplating driving over there now to satisfy my craving for more boat noodles!
author: Connie C.

description:
This place rocks!!! I ordered delivery/tried them for the first time this evening.

Their combos are a SUPER good deal, and I absolutely loved the Tom Yum soup I ordered (I added shrimp which was the right choice, delicious ). Super speedy delivery too. I'll definitely be ordering from here again!
author: Pam S.

description: I have become a regular even though it's not in my neighborhood because it is so damn good! Try the pumpkin curry dish!
author: Mike S.

description: I really like this place.  Over the years the food became better, then went through a bit of a slump, and now has came back with a vengeance.  The best part is, it is family owned.  The owner is one of the nicest guys you could meet and still makes deliveries as well as manages his business.  He and his wife make sure everyone feels welcomed and the staff's inviting smiles makes eating here a pleasurable experience from the start.  But the food, the food will have you coming back time and time again.  My tip of the day: try the boat noodle bowl. The small is under 3 bucks and is well worth the try.
author: Christian H.

description:
I've been living in my apt in the TL for almost 4 years, and it has been a struggle to find a delish Thai delivery which all my friends enjoyed their meals.  With so many Thai restaurants over here, you would think this wouldn't be such a challenge!

Ordered our usual Thai restaurant faves using Eat 24: pad kee mao, iced teas, chicken wings, listed my food allergies, hoped for the best.  Food shows up in 30 mins, super hot, sauces separated and unspilled, teas strategically wrapped without too much waste, and everything was absolutely delicious!!!

Seriously, $2 Thai iced tea that is soooooo good!!!  The chicken wings are called "Wings of Lovers" and its true, because we loved them.  They were actually really hearty wings and the sauce was excellent.  The pad kee mao has really wide noodles compared to what I usually see in places.  Delicious.

Thank goodness, the takeout Thai crisis is finally over!
author: Katie S.

description: My wife, who is Thai, absolutely loves this restaurant.  We will drive all the way into the city just to eat here. The food is authentic and fresh every time we go. The parking is sometimes tough and don't let the surroundings outside scare you off. This place has great food and service and you will leave there happy and full. I highly recommend.
author: Mark E.

description: Tried delivery tonight and although it took an hour- it was worth the wait. So tasty, fresh, flavorful, and piping hot. I like that there is online ordering too. Good portions and reasonable prices.
author: Misty M.

description:
Maybe we ordered the wrong dishes but I thought the food was okay. 

Zen Yai Platter - The fried eggroll, fried calmari, and fried shrimp was okay. It came with a sweet sauce.

Crazy Sea - Combination seafood (shrimps, scallop, calamari & mussel in garlic chili sauce and in a hot sizzling pan - It sounded good, but it was similar to Chinese food.

Pad Thai - The pad thai was okay. The noodles were not mushy but wish there was more stuff in the pad thai. 

The good thing about this place is that the prices are cheap considering that we're in San Francisco. Portions are on the smaller side. Area is a bit sketchy though. 


Link to website: https://webpos.wlinformation.com/zen-yai-thai-san-francisco/
author: Jackie S.

description:
It was 11pm, I had just gotten home from work on a Friday night and the husband says, "I want Thai food, delivered." So we take to yelp to satiate his needs. Since that's what he needs at 11pm on a Friday night. 

I digress...

After a few calls to restaurants who claimed to be open late, but mysteriously closed early when we asked for delivery, I was happy that Zen Yai was happy to deliver to us (now at 11:15). We ordered the pad thai, the pad khe mao, and the combo #3 (he was really hungry) and it was here by 11:40! That was great. 

But the food was just eh...actually the yellow curry that came with the combo #3 was the best thing we had. Everything else needed a little help and luckily we had peanut sauce, sweet chili sauce, shiracha, and knives and forks here since we needed them all. I'm not sure I'll eat the leftovers, but I'm sure the husband will. But that's not saying much. 

So tonight I give you props, Zen Yai, for your yellow curry, your very speedy delivery, being open later night, your kind delivery guy who wished us happy New Year and was really sweet, and your abundant amount of food that left us filled up. I'd say, maybe work on the chicken in the combo and kick up the peanut flavor just a bit...but then again, maybe that's my uncultured, American Thai loving palate talking. If so, just keep doing what you're doing. 

Now back to my wine.
author: Cessalee S.

description:
I must admit, I was a little hesitant, and mildly suspicious, when my cousin suggested going to a very cheap, but tasty Thai restaurant in the TL for lunch last week. This suspicion grew the further in we tread, as the smells of unwashed bodies and sun-dried urine slowly grew stronger and stronger. Imagine my relief when we ended up at Zen Yai, a place that'd been on my Yelp bookmarks for several months now.

Between the three of us, we got two orders of boat noodles, a duck soup noodle [ http://flic.kr/p/cfz5fo ], and green curry chicken. While the two noodle dishes were definitely tasty (the boat noodles in particular), the green curry was lackluster, lacking in both flavor and spice (despite us asking for it to be spicy). 

Portions were not massive, but filling, and good for the prices. Service was friendly, and there wasn't a wait, with the restaurant only at 1/4-1/3 capacity when we were there (a little after lunch). I can definitely see myself coming back for their noodles, for which I'll give them 3.5 stars.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I've been to the restaurant once and have ordered via Eat24 numerous times. The restaurant itself is okay. Service is alright. I had ordered yum woon sen and asked for mild. It was so incredibly spicy. I returned the order in exchange for non spicy, which was actually still a bit spicy. Sigh. 

Ordering Eat24 is convenient. They are usually super quick, and the portions are huge. Each noodle, soup, and rice dish have all been divided into three meals for me. Their food is delicious, but I have one major qualm - they add waaaaay too much MSG. I actually just ate half of my veggie pad thai, and I feel extremely nauseous. It was also very, very salty. Though, because of the MSG, I continued to eat til I felt faint... Yeah, it's that tasty. 

I'll probably not order anymore rice and noodle dishes. The shrimp rice roll is quite delicious. I'll just stick to that.
author: Lin C.

description: This is probably the closest thing to having authentic boat noodles in this city than having it in Thailand. I know this because I've been to Thailand and this restaurant has it down to the T. Too bad it's not $1.25 here as it is in Thailand haha try the pink noodles too if you like seafood. The boat noodles has a deep beef flavored broth, beef balls, slices of beef, ong choy veggies and fried pork skins. Mmm drooling already. Get the big bowl or sample it for just $2.50 for a tiny bowl. But after you sampled it, you would want to get the big bowl. I like to get the wide flat noodles in mine. If you like seafood get the pink noodles. It comes with squid, fish and squid balls, white fungus, ong choy veggies and crispy fried wide noodles.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Overhyped IMHO. Ordered delivery here on a recent trip to SF. The food was mediocre at best. I got the following:

Tod Mun (Fish Cakes): 1/5
Honestly I could not even make out if there was any fish in it, felt like all batter albeit moist yet fully cooked batter. But batter none the less.

Zen Yai Fresh Roll: 3.5/5
By far the best part of the order. The rolls and the filling was fresh. The peanut sauce was good.

Pad Thai Noodle: 2/5
It was among the worst pad thai's I've eaten based on flavor. I mostly ate the chicken, tofu and shrimp and left the noodles as they were quite underwhelming.

Besides not being impressed with the food in general, the bag that food was delivered in had an awful rotten fish smell which has already settled into my hotel room in the couple of minutes it took me to figure out what the source was. It took me hours to vent the smell out of the room.
author: Dheer G.

description: Been coming here for a couple years off and on.  As others have said, try the boat noodles. Unless you hate flavor.  The women that run the place are nice and the atmosphere is pretty quaint when it's not busy. This place makes me want to visit Thailand again.
author: Julian C.

description:
We came here to try the "boat noodles", which is not on their regular printed menu.
It was $6.95 for a delicious bowl of thick, hearty, savory soup.
When ordering, you get your choice of meat (beef or pork) and choice of noodles (small, fried, egg, clear cellophane).  I opted for the most popular options, which were beef and the fried noodles.  
The broth is less spicy than it initially looks, but it's still got a kick.  There's a nice texture with their addition of crispy pork rinds on top.  

We came here to split a bowl of these noodles while we were waiting for a table at Brenda's, since they had an hour long wait.  However I would come back again to make this the star dish of my day.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
It's only okay. Been here twice for lunch and order the Combo #2 each time. The pad thai is good, but there is something lacking with the curry. It's plenty of food, including a baseball-sized round of rice, two fried wontons, a little salad, a small portion of pad thai with two shrimp (which they do not devein very well... I had to clean shrimp poop from my shrimp both times I was there... not ideal), and a small bowl of curry with potatoes and I guess what passes for chicken these days.

Next time I go I think I'll avoid the combo and just have the pad thai.
author: N'olo J.

description:
Wow, service is almost nonexistent, too bad food is good. 

Ordered and received a very good pumpkin curry. Received a tiny 8oz glass of water to go with my spicy premium curry, and then waitress disappeared entirely until asking "are you done" and brought my check after I affirmed. Left me with a bone dry water glass as she passed me by several times to full glasses and tend to other needs of table right beside me. Wow. After a while I just hung back quietly to see if she was that oblivious to her tables or not. Yup, she wanted that multiple-party tip - even cleared their dishes while ignoring mine piled up on a smaller table.

4.5 stars for the food, but minus 2.5 stars for the McDonalds-level service ("here's your food, here's your invoice"). 

Too bad, as I am hosting some friends next week who really want to have Thai, this place is now off the running. And, I'm giving a McDonalds-level tip today - aka $0.00
author: Bob M.

description:
So we found this place on the app EAT24.

Delivery wasn't super quick but that's okay since we weren't in a rush. 

That said, the good part here was the food. For only $20 (tip and delivery included) we had completely full stomachs.
We ordered 2 Combo #2's which have - pad thai, yellow curry and wontons. We were stuffed and even had food leftover. 

Satisfied, full, and delicious
...FOR ONLY $20!!

I'm reviewing this so I can remember which spot to try again next time we're hungry and lazy - ha
author: Hiro R.

description: I fricking love Thai food.  And I loved Zen Yai Thai.  This place was recommended to me by someone whose reviews I did not yet trust, but it did not disappoint.  Definitely the boat noodles are super amazing with a very rich broth, good noodles, and good overall flavour, and the pumpkin curry was really good too.  The boat noodles reminded me of a trip I took to Bangkok, and I dragged my parents to eat by this roadside "restaurant" where everyone was eating boat noodles by the bowls - some people looked like they had ordered 10 or so each!  Of course those bowls were much much smaller, and probably 10 US cents/bowl, so it was a nice nostalgic feeling for me.  Additionally, we ordered a crab noodle which was not great, so super not worth it considering how good the other stuff was.
author: Michelle L.

description: For first time visitors, just be aware that the small boat noodle for $2.50 is VERY TINY. Food here is alright. And unless you happen to be in the area, I wouldn't go out of the way to dine here.
author: Natalia H.

description: Amazing food !! Love it !! When I was taking lunch here I feel like I am in Thailand now !! Love spicy ! Especially Papaya salad with Lao style !! Hmm
author: Zaw Win T.

description:
We came based on other reviews, but our experience was far different. We ordered chicken satay, thom kha, pad woon sen, and pad se-ew. The pad woon sen came out first. About 5 min later the soup. Then the satay and other dish. Not sure why an entree came out before the other items. The thom kha broth was bland and didn't seem like much care went into making it. The satay was not well seasoned either and rather bland. 
The waiter never came back to check on us after taking our order. Kitchen staff brought our food. Not sure what the issue was because other people who seemed to be friends of the wait staff received plenty of attention. 

Our bland food got cold pretty quick as well because it was freezing in the place.  The pad woon sen and pad se ew was decent, but not the best.  This is not a place I would return to or recommend based on today's experience.
author: Lori O.

description: This Thai restaurant is a highly recommended  by my District Manager who is Thai.  The service and food was really good, especially the boat noodle,  and the Thai tea, Thanks Nat!!
author: Foodie L.

description: This place was really REALLY good.  We ordered pad see ew, wings, wonton soup and pork boat noodle and everything was good.  Had to be some of the best Pad See Ew Ive had in a long time.  The area is pretty shady, but definitely worth going to late night for the food
author: Tommy A.

description:
I wish I could give Zen Yai ZERO stars.

My roommate and I ordered here on grubhub... TWO THUMBS DOWN.

She got- Chicken Eggplant. Looked like taco bell ground beef (not resembling chicken at all) and had a very thick, flavorless, sugary glaze over the whole thing. She had half and wouldn't eat it. I have a cast iron stomach, so I made an attempt, but it was honestly just gross.

I got- Kow Opp Mor Din- which was definitely the better of the two, but as you can see, is not saying much. I couldn't really bring myself to eat the leftovers of this either. 

The delivery people were 30 minutes late, got our order wrong ( I received no soup and PAID EXTRA for 2 rices and only got 1 rice, the one that APPARENTLY CAME IN MY DISH FOR FREE). They didn't bring silverware or napkins, arrived late, didn't have soy sauce, and honestly made a horrible scene by stopping the car in the middle of the street to----no, not BRING THE FOOD TO MY DOOR---but rather, to wave at me to come into the street (while cars were behind, honking), to retrieve all of the food. The soup lid wasn't on all the way, spilled, and burned my arm.

not impressed.

I would also like to note that I have found better Thai food in OKLAHOMA. That's all.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Underrated Thai Place in the Tenderloin (mainly bc it's not on Larkin but in between Polk St. and Larkin).  

Had the Combo Fried Rice, it was awesome.

I also like the place bc of its modern decor.
author: Joshua P.

description: i decided to give this place a shot twice and the food here is just ok. nothing really special to rant and rave about because there are so many thai restaurants in the neighborhood now. At times when the place is semi packed the service can be very very slow. One major thing i noticed on my second time back there was a lot of people order noodles. Maybe i was ordering the wrong thing the entire time. ill give this place another shot and if it does not wow my taste buds there are plenty of other thai places in the area that will do it for me.
author: Art N.

description:
I never post reviews but this place is amazing. My boyfriend and I are going to Thailand so we wanted to find the most authentic thai restaurant in the city. This may be it!! We love it so much we come almost every week. Be sure to order the bbq thai pork with thai sauce. This is amazing with the sticky rice. Also get the pad kee mao - extra spicy! So good! 

Don't forget the beer! It's BYOB and the beer really helps with the spiciness.
author: Roz M.

description: Very tasty yellow curry paired with some yummy spicy noodles and tofu! Definitely will be coming here again.
author: anita m.

description:
In the past 2 months, I've been to Zen Yai Thai 5 times. You can say I am addicted. I always go there for the Thai Boat Noodles in beef or pork and  Yen Ta For (fermented bean soup) noodles. These are their house specialties listed on the wall written in Thai. The noodles are small bowl for $2.50 each. The serving size is the same as the ones you get in Thailand, 3 to 4 bites. I also eat 2 to 3 bowls and feel super satisfied afterwards. The broth is the winner here. The Thai Boat Noodles broth is thick, hearty, delicious and full of flavors. You can just tell it was slow stewing for a long time. 

The last 2 visits I ordered a few items from their regular menu, the green papaya salad is crunchy and the lime juice is refreshing. The fish cake, sauteed Chinese mustard green with crispy BBQ pork, and Green Curry Fried Rice are on point. The Chicken Larb is the real McCoy, it is done just like the way in Thailand - mixed with toasted rice. 

So far everything I tried on the Thai board menu and the regular menu are super delicious, very authentic, the price is affordable, and the service is great. I am going again tomorrow with my Thai friend and you can be sure I'm getting the Thai Boat Noodles Soup again.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
Beware: FOOD POISONING!

As other reviewers have already pointed out, this restaurant does not use fresh ingredients and in some cases food is spoiled or rotten. I ordered via Eat24 and had the Pad Se-Ew Noodles and Green Curry Fried Rice, one of the two dishes gave me food poisoning. I have not been that sick in many years; if I could have gotten myself out of bed I would have gone to an emergency room.

It's easy to dismiss this as a one-off case until you read through some of the other reviews here. Something is pathologically broken in the way this place handles food and my advice is to avoid it.
author: Max C.

description:
Note: this is a review of delivery service/delivery thru EAT24.com  

I never got to try the food because the food never came.  An hour and a half after I ordered my food (with an original 45-60min delivery time), I called the restaurant directly who said they never received an order for me from eat24.  Now I'm struggling to get a refund from eat24 who has my money.

So an hour and 40 mins later, no food for me and my bf and i'm struggling to get my money back.  Awesome.  The food here might be great so I feel bad writing a bad review for the restaurant but there is a problem somewhere.  

Too bad =/
author: Mary A.

description:
Pretty damn good for lunch.

I like the open floor plan, and the service is quick and friendly.
author: L J.

description:
+ authentic
+ get the $2.50 noodle soup! my fav part of my meal. so flavorful. 
+ green curry was yum!
author: Margaret R.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend's family on a saturday for lunch. Parking wasn't too hard. The place had interesting decor, nice and roomy also.

My bf is thai so they ordered in thai and i had no idea what they were getting.

food came out pretty quick!

duck noodle soup! very tasty broth, yum big flat rice noodles.

then came the boat noodles in tiny bowls. I think it was 2.50 for a bowl so we ordered like 8 of them and 2 of the yen ta 4.

the boat noodles were delicious but you do have to eat at least 3 bowls to be full. they're like pho, but a thicker broth and saltier/sweetier. very heavy

the yen ta 4 is a red soup with seafood and i don't like it asss much as the boat noodles but still good to try.

spicy yummy filling! would love to come back again!
author: Christine M.

description:
I use to love ordering from here unfortunately I NEVER will again!! The food was pretty good despite the small portions but the service is always horrible! No matter if I order on the phone or in person the people taking the orders are just not friendly or helpful. On several occasions they have been flat out rude!! 
Once I ordered egg fried rice with my meal and they only sent over a fried egg. When I called to get the situation rectified they told me the kitchen was closed and couldn't make the rice (it was the only item out of my order that was actually for me). 
I recently called to just give it one more shot however the person on the phone put me on hold for over 7 min. I would have just hung up but I was unsure if she even placed my order or not. 
If I order using the app they do not get the special request section so the food doesn't come the way it's requested. 
Needless to say this is just a few small examples of the bad service they give regularly to frequent returning customers.
author: Rindi C.

description:
I came here for one thing, and one thing ONLY - the Boat noodle!

A friend of mine who's Thai took me here and insisted that I should try their boat noodle soup (off the menu). Now I'm a fan! It is dirt cheap and amazingly delicious. This is a much thicker and flavorful soup than for example the roast duck noodle soup. It's almost like a dark color stew with either pork or beef of your choice with meat balls, chives and pork rinds. I like the pad thai rice vermicelli noodle in the soup. They have two sizes - I usually just get two small ones for about 2.50 dollars each. It seems like the small is half of the size of the large but the large costs about 1 dollar more... not that it makes a big difference but im just saying it's better to get two small, you can change up the meat or the choice of noodle!

I didn't give 5 stars for the restaurant since I've only tried one thing there! But the boat noodle is definitely worth 5 stars!
author: Mindy C.

description:
Nice decor, I LOVE  the big huge (redundant I know, I am naturally  enthusiastic which brings out the repetitiveness)  copper gong,  on the wall, I want that thing.  

Okay! the food? You want to know about the food.  

My rotund friend ordered the green sea soup ...he has eaten a LOT of food.  Do you actually hear me? I am CREOLE from New Orleans Louisiana...just for those who did not have time to read my bio...yes I COOK(s)!  I do it right. Gumbo, jambalya, muffaletta ...I am the real deal.  This New Yorker ordered the green sea soup and said "This is da best soup I eva had.

So the check was right, the staff was tight and the food was great, now YOU go there and tell me what you ordered!
author: BellaLissa B.

description: $2 for a small bowl of boat noodle and $3 Yen-ta-fo. Flavorful and very authentic. Too bck I wasn't that hungry or else I would have double ordered.
author: Robin S.

description: The Best Thai boat noodle soup in San Francisco! The taste of thai boat noodle in Zen Yai is athletic. They also have thai desseet too. For another dish I think the taste is so so but I give 4 stars for the Thai boat noodle!!!
author: Orange S.

description: Real Thai food. Five stars for very authentic Thai noodle dishes and papaya salad. Very few Thai restaurants make an effort at authentic food. Zen Yai does hence the large Thai clientele. The not noodles are amazing. You get get a large or small bowl. I suggest getting a small bowel of each of the three specialty noose types and a Papua salad with preserved crab. Spicy heaven. Service is substandard here, but who cares with the great food.
author: Steve C.

description:
I was heading over to Hai Ky Mi Gia for duck noodles, when I felt the urge for Thai food instead. Tap tap on the iPhone and Zen Yai came up, so I ran up Ellis Street and bounced in thinking that pumpkin curry on a west-coast chilly day would hit the spot.

Their pumpkin was solid! Good mixture of veggies and kabocha. The animal meat proteins of chicken and shrimp were generous in portions. The curry sauce was very savory and not overly seasoned.

Service: friendly and attentive.
Location: not the 'effed up portion of Tenderloin, so whew.
Overall a great dish, so I'll probably be back to try some other dishes
author: Derek N.

description:
FOOD:
1.) boat noodle = O man, only $2.50 for a thing of boat noodle soup. This was really yummy too!
2.) pad kee mao = ooh hit the spot. yummy. 



SERVICE:
Good


ATMOSPHERE:
Casual, open, clean Thai restaurant. :P
author: Angela L.

description:
The food I had was great. I had ordered from grubhub.com again and the service was just as I had remembered; it was quick, food was still hot upon arrival and I had a full, happy tummy after nom'n the food. :]

The entrees were fairly priced. I had ordered the spicy chicken ($6.95) with white rice for my bf and the clay pot rice (kow opp mor din @ $7.95) for myself and the sticky rice & mango ($4.25)  to finish off the meal (to cap off the $15 minimum for free delivery).  

From when the food was ordered to it's arrival time, it had taken roughly 35-40 minutes. I wasn't disappointed because it arrived in time just as the email had said it would. I was very pleased with how delicious both entrees were and I was surprised at how the mangoes were so sweet!! 

We ate our lunch quietly (meaning we definitely liked it) and were completely satisfied.
author: Carol L.

description:
This place serves up some pretty authentic Thai noodle soups up in NorCal. So authentic that they even serve the noodles in tiny Thai portion (that is about 3-5 mouthfuls per bowl, depending on whether you inhale or not). One story behind the small portion was that these noodles were traditionally served on rocking boats. Small portion made it harder to spill the hot soup.

That leads me to the infamous boat noodles. The ones here packs a good depth of complex flavors: savory, spicy and sour. The beef was tender, and it comes with a decent meat ball and some pork rinds. They don't seem to serve the noodles with liver (which is fine by me).

I also quite like the Yentafo (which is thick rice sticks in a pink broth topped with fish balls and blood pudding I think. The pink came from preserved red beancurd "Namyee" or "Nanru"). But the Yentafo was a tad on the salty side, probably due to the Namyee.

If you want to eat like you are in Thailand, order as many bowls as you wish. Then stack the emptied bowls high to mark your achievement. But don't forget to save room for their yum (salad) offerings. Glass noodles with pork and shrimps/squid or Larb!

The place is clean and the staff is friendly.
author: A. W.

description: Customer beware that they do not allow you to change anything. I asked for yellow curry, easy potato, add broccoli. They absolutely refused. I got two huge pieces of potato and two gigantic pieces of chicken. They also do not have tofu. That being said, the customer service was just okay and despite the hang up with the modifications the food was exceptional. I'll be back on a day that Im cheating on my diet.
author: Savannah Veronica J.

description:
Ordered to go once and got some delicious seafood soup.  Walked in to order for lunch-something described as "wide egg noodle"; waited 25 minutes- the place was otherwise empty, got something like chinese chow mein, greasy sloppy, blech.
Sitting there waiting for so long gave me an opportunity to peep the cleanliness of the place...YIKES!
author: Eric S. R.

description:
I'm in love with their 2.50 boat noodle.

Everything was yummy. Service was a bit slow the day I went in though. Still, good price for good food. I shall be back...
author: Ames A.

description:
First time ever having Boat Noodles and I must say it is DELICIOUS!!!!!!  I ordered it for delivery because it was highly recommended from my friend Hazel.  

Boat noodle is not on the menu...its on the special menu on the wall per Hazel.

How I ordered my Boat:
flat noodles with beef, no onions, no cilantro. :)

It comes with beef balls, pork Rhine's, pork, and spinach.

I will defiantly order from Zen Yai again!!!!!
author: Sandy L.

description:
I love this place! It was the only Thai restaurant that I could stomach 3 months after coming back from Thailand. 

Their boat noodles are to-die-for if you love a dark black stewy gravy poured over noodles. The depth of its flavor never ceases to amaze me. I also love their fried wontons and chicken wings. Be aware that the chicken wings are on the sweet side!

One of my favorites in SF.
author: Nina D.

description: Ordered food to get delivered over the weekend. Tried their boat noodles, spicy chicken salad, papaya salad and pad thai. The boat noodles were so good! so much flavor. The spicy chicken salad was very disappointing. too much rice powder. tasted blan and mealy. Papaya salad was fresh and good so was the Pad Thai. Will definitely order food from here again.
author: Allen L.

description:
The spicy here is no joke. If you miss the usual 'thai-level' spiciness, come to this place. Decor is very simple, not much things to adore, but menu is pretty extensive. 

Dishes to look out for:

The green curry fried rice is probably the best I've tried so far. Very bold, rice is moist, absorbs the curry and spices. Excellent.

Secret menu: small-serving thick, hearty bowl of beef/pork rice noodles. Somewhat sweet, and really spicy. Not sure how you can control the spiciness here. 

Som Tam (Papaya salad) Mmmmm. Really tasty. Papaya is at its right texture and ripeness. Too bad they don't include the green beans which is often added to this dish.

Tilapia/Catfish with ChooChee sauce. Gosh. So good. So, first the fish is deepfried, then it's sauteed with this red-curry paste creating a nice delicate gravy to eat with the rice that's served on the side.

Definitely a great neighborhood spot. Price is damn reasonable. $6.95 for that fried rice.. Whatttt!!
author: Rika P.

description:
I usually frequent the other Thai places around the neighborhood (Lers Ros, Bang San, Sai Jai, etc), so I decided to be a bit more adventurous and try this place out. I read on Yelp that I must try their "boat noodles" from their secret menu. When I was at the restaurant, a lot of patrons ordered boat noodles, but after trying it, I'm not so sure what's so special about them? It's a so-so noodle soup with poor quality meat. I would pass.

Their menu is pretty standard, and we ordered a crab fried rice and a bbq chicken red curry. The curry was decent, but lacking in meat. The fried rice was meh. There was a really strong "fish" taste to it, but in an overwhelming kind of way. It seemed like they just dumped a bunch of shrimp paste in it to pass off as having crab because there was practically no crab in the fried rice. The only crab bit I saw was a claw (still in its shell) that was stringy and tasteless. :(
author: H. L.

description: Boat noodles !!!! So delicious & it has so much flavor. Awesome thai place with reasonable price and bYOB! ;)
author: Sandy L.

description:
YES YES YES. 

Apparently those special noodles reviewed below are something to write home about....but I am SCRIBBLING RAVENOUSLY about the pumpkin curry. Hands down, the best pumpkin curry in/around San Francisco. Prices seemed right, plenty of seating, and a warm environment- even the bathroom was nice!

-For $9.99, the pumpkin curry comes in red curry along with red bell peppers, basil, shrimp, and TENDER chicken. The portions were large (i was full after half the plate and actually just finished my leftovers- BRB SOBBING). There are cheaper lunch specials but the pumpkin curry was not an eligible meal
-The service was quick and FRIENDLY- now don't get me wrong. I'm Asian and I will fully resign that we have the worst service in the restaurant industry. I even asked to replace the shrimp with more pumpkin (yeah I'm one of THOSE patrons) and they gladly obliged.
-Situated right around Civic Center, and though the restaurant is technically in the Tenderloin, the area is not dodgy as it's part of the Polk/Van Ness area
-They deliver
-Accepts credit cards
-Plays fun pop music: Loud enough to accompany your happy mouth dance, but not too obnoxious that you can't have a decent conversation

I will definitely be back!
author: Jan C.

description:
THAI BOAT NOODLES. JUST DO IT.  You will not regret it.  My favorite one was the one with the soup with pigs blood.  The boat noodle menu is written on the wall in Thai, so don't disregard the chalkboard!!! 

Another plus, the colorful cast of characters hanging out outside the restaurant.
author: Ali C.

description: My family has been coming here for years. Their food is always delicious, and very reasonably priced. We love their Pad Thai, Tom Yum soup, all their Curry dishes, Barbecue Pork, and Spicy Calamari. A lot of people come here for their "boat noodles," which is a small bowl of noodle soup that is jam-packed with sauces and spices. You definitely need to try it!
author: Jackie B.

description:
best boat noodles in norcal Ive had but it was a lil too salty, didnt see any liver in it :( . we got the large bowl and it had a tiny amount of noodles, asked the buff dude waiter guy if we could pay for extras noodles and he was pretty clueless about it and just walked away.

got a small bowl of yen ta fo also since the boat noodles was hella small and that bowl was like 2-3 bites you can pick up almost everything in the bowl at once with chopsticks.
author: Phuc B.

description:
A great Thai place that is never too busy. Everything is quite tasty here, and one can get by just on the boat noodles, which are not on the menu but clearly displayed on the wall. You have a few choices when it comes to meat, type of noodle, spiciness, etc. I usually go with beef and get the wide noodles and all the toppings.

The duck dish here is tasty and flavorful. Good vegetarian choices too, and some unusual drinks like Palm drink.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I've ate one of the most delicious dishes in my life ever here.

It came to me as a complete surprise because I actually asked the server for his suggestion.  He told me to get their Spicy Pumpkin Curry.  I was slightly skeptical because I am not usually a fan of pumpkin dishes, but this one is more than just an exception.  I was AMAZED (not exaggerating) at how scrumptious this dish was.  I will be thinking about it for weeks, but it will only be a matter of days before I go back. Definitely recommend!

The area seems kinda rough but the place is nice inside, definitely a diamond in the dirt.
author: Carlos R.

description:
14.12.26        1st sit in dinner
                        many times for lunch or take out

Food ---------------------  3 1/2 to 4 depending on dishes
Service -------------------  3 1/2

Too many dishes to critique ... matter or personal taste

Our group had some of the following:
Crazy Sea
Pad Yang
Seafood Claypot
Pineapple Fried Rice
Pad Kee Mao
Spicy Tofu
Pad Se Ew w Beef
Veggie Tofu Eggplant
Pad Pak Peanut Sauce and Tofu

and several specials written in Thai on the wall

Most of the dishes are pretty good.
Too many to go into details.
It is matter of personal preference and taste.
You should try some of the "wall specials" if u are bold.
author: S.K. Y.

description: If you want a true thai food experience, Zen Yai is it! Met friends here but already had thai for lunch (at a place not as good that will remain nameless). So, I decided to get something different...the chicken noodle soup! It was totally delicious and I order it often. We ordered apps and a variety of meals and everything was so good! Plus, this restaurant also delivers!
author: Janelle G.

description: I like this restaurant for delivery. Quality of food was fine. But this time, delivery call me come down to apartment instead of he came up, because he double parked on the street. So of course I come down to apartment. But he parked on the parking spot right in front of my apartment, and he was waiting in the car.  He lazy to come up and he just move few steps out of his car to deliver food to me. Never order here again.
author: Jay H.

description:
If I still worked in the area, this would probably be my go to Thai spot.  Food is good, prices are reasonable, and its a close enough walk to the Civic Center where you can't complain too much.  Now reflecting on present day, where I only venture to these parts maybe once a month, and not even during the day, I'd probably see less of this place.  Nevertheless, its good to keep on the back of my mind when I want some good ol curry or noodles or what not.

For their lunch special, I had the duck red curry, which comes with your standard side of salad and some rice to go with.  Easily DEVOURED.  And at $7 a pop, it's almost as good as your local neighborhood King of Thai.  Yes, I did....I compared this place to King of Thai, because King of Thai is great!
author: Vincent K.

description: I must say I've had some awful Thai food and some good Thai food. But so far, this is definitely the best Thai food I've had in the city. Even for delivery! The Spicy chicken plate is so delicious, my husband practically breathed it in! Their fried rice actually is flavorful enough that I don't need soy sauce. And the Pad See Ew noodles are cooked perfectly, with the right amount of flavor. Normally, when I order pad see ew, the chicken I get with it is very bland or dry, not theirs! I will definitely be a regular.
author: Jennifer W.

description: If you can't read Thai, find someone who can.  Their Thai menu has awesome dishes that are so comforting!  Their boat noodle broth is amazing without seasoning, very well balanced.  This is a late review, but I really need to make the drive out.  They also offer Som Tum Tard which is a papaya salad platter filled with meat, noodles an assortment of veggies.  If you're looking for items seen at every other Thai restaurant they also have that.  Oh and Kao Mun Gai, looks simple but the sauce makes the dish, a must try!
author: Marlena P.

description:
My friend brought me here a few weeks back and said that a lot of his Thai friends come here for their food (specifically this boat noodle soup) and they would rave about it.  After eating here, I told him a lot of my Chinese friends like Panda Express as well but it doesn't make them an expert just because they are Chinese.  

If this restaurant was running on all cylinders, the quality of food would be at best 3 stars.  There's just nothing here that really stands out.  Everything is just average.  If you wanted a definition of mediocrity, this is it.   Can't sugar coat it.  With so many options to choice from especially in the TL, you can do so much better.

The broth was just very plain, the service was very nonchalant, and the ambiance just felt as though they could be also selling lottos, snacks, and other tidbits.
author: jason g.

description:
Zen Yai Thai has very reasonable prices, a good selection of dishes, and a very tasty special boat noodle that is NOT on the regular menu. For $2.95 for a mini bowl of spicy soup noodles; they can't be beat. Their combo dishes are a good option if you want a variety of dishes all to yourself. 

Key takeaways:

1. Get the Boat Noodles. 
2. Combo options are a good size with good variety. 
3. Good spot for a quick Thai bite. Consider it an option comparable to King of Thai type food.
author: Denny C.

description:
I was really expecting so much more from this place.  Perhaps we ordered the "wrong things"....but I was really hoping their whole menu would taste excellent, not just select items.  

We ordered the red veggie and tofu curry, tom yum soup with tofu, pad kee mao with shrimp and spicy bbq spare ribs (something like that).  

The curry was just okay.  It was actually quite disappointing.  The tom yum was very good.  Pad kee mao lacked flavor.  This was probably one of my least favorite pad kee mao that I've ever tried.  The spice ribs were very tough and the meat was just weird, unlike one you'd order at a chinese restaurant.  (Yes, I realize this isn't a Chinese restaurant but that's all I can think to compare it to.)  

The service was fine.  The location of the restaurant was kind of ghetto.  Probably wouldn't come back based on location alone.  Oh well, win some, lose some!
author: R R.

description: One star because their driver didn't read the important note I included on the Eat24 order. I had a sick baby and sick wife both sleeping so I asked them not to ring the doorbell and only call me. He did call me....and then proceeded to buzz to loud doorbell about 15 times as I came down to let him in. Hopefully they read this and instruct their drivers a bit better in the future.
author: Todd L.

description:
While there are more than a dozon of Thai resturants in Tendoloin,  I have to say some are quite commericialized and not very distinctive.  We discovered this authenic Thai place from yelp that is within a few minutes of walk from my place.  You can tell the minute you walk in that this place serves real Thai food from the Thai-based clientile. The authenticity of Thai food is assessed by the sauce and spice.  Their boat noodle at $2.50 is a must try.  It is a very small portion so if you're hungry, get two!  Their stir fry wide rice noodles are also very flavorable and plainly yummy.   

The place opens late on Friday nights and has plenty of seating.  The service is also very good.  Highly-recommended!
author: Susan C.

description:
Very authentic. Has the thai noodle soups on the wall, written in Thai.

Luckily we had someone who could read thai with us so she hooked us up with the order. Those soups are def the best part. They're a little small so you can order a couple and try different flavors. 
The neighborhood is def seedy, but it's ok, you're not eating outside.
author: Shanee B.

description: They called after i submitted my order and said it will take 1.5hrs for delivery. I said that's ok, just get here as quick as you can. 1:45minutes pass and I call them and they said my order was canceled.  They did apology but did not offer to remedy the problem.
author: jayme c.

description: Love the fried wonton and the spicy mince chicken over rice. Service is friendly and helpful. Ask for jessy. She took care of us.
author: dave w.

description: Service is great. The food is delicious. There's not an over powering smell or flavor of fish sauce like many of the restaurants. Curries, soups and rice dishes are all very well prepared. The prices can't be beat either.
author: Kevin-louis B.

description: Noodles here is good but service need to be improve. Server here not very attentive even though restaurant is not busy. I'm normally a good tipper but with their services they lucky to get some tips from me.
author: Angkana P.

description: The best noodles soup intown papaya salad is the Thai test. Service is nice we will be back again
author: yagusa t.
